question: How does a Listed Entity get approval to issue Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme, and what happens next for listing?
answer: A Listed Entity must first ensure that its Employee Incentive Scheme is approved correctly. If the scheme was set up before the Securities were listed, the entity should have included the scheme's details and the number of Securities to be issued in its prospectus or documents filed with the Regulator. If the scheme is an exception, the entity's shareholders must approve it, and the meeting notice should include the scheme's terms, past issuances, and the maximum number of Securities to be issued. After these steps, the Securities can be admitted to the Official List. This admission becomes effective only when the Regulator publishes it by adding the Securities to the Official List on the ADGM website. This process ensures that the entity complies with both internal and external requirements for issuing and listing Securities [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] and [#TGT:d28d3376-4af3-4b11-b90d-3f24c8e54555].
source_passage_text: An issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme if within three years before the issue date: (a) in the case of a scheme established before the Listed Entitys Securities were admitted to the Official List a summary of the terms of the scheme and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme were set out in in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or (b) the holders of the Listed Entitys Ordinary Securities have approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme as an exception to Rule 9.7.1. The notice of meeting must have included: (i) a summary of the terms of the scheme; (ii) the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entitys Securities were admitted to the Official List, or the date of the last approval under this Rule; and (iii) the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval.
target_passage_text: Listing application. An admission of Securities to the Official List becomes effective only when the Regulator has published the admission by adding such Securities to the Official List on the ADGM website.

question: When can the Regulator decide not to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action for an ADGM Branch, and what must be true for them to take a Resolution Action?
answer: The Regulator can choose not to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action if it believes that doing so would harm financial stability in the ADGM or if certain conditions related to the entity have not been met. For the Regulator to take a Resolution Action on an ADGM Branch, it must see that the branch is failing or likely to fail and that no other actions can reasonably prevent this. It also needs to be in the public interest, and the Non-ADGM Institution should not be under any Foreign Resolution Action unless specific conditions apply. These rules help the Regulator make sure that any actions taken are necessary and in the best interest of financial stability [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] and [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba].
source_passage_text: A Resolution Action may be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the following conditions are met (a) the ADGM Branch is failing or is likely to fail; (b) having regard to timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action will be taken by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution that will prevent the failure or likely failure of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution; (c) the application of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and (d) the Non-ADGM Institution is (i) not subject to, and not likely in a reasonable timeframe to be subject to, any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings; or (ii) subject to Foreign Resolution Action, and one of the circumstances referred to in section 78(2) applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution.
target_passage_text: The Regulator may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part if it is satisfied that one or more of the following conditions are met— (a) recognition would have an adverse effect on financial stability in the ADGM; (b) the Resolution Conditions have not been met in relation to the entity listed in section 2 with respect to which the Regulator proposes to take Resolution Action pursuant to section 78(5); (c) the taking of Resolution Action by the Regulator in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5) is not necessary to achieve one or more of the Resolution Objectives; (d) under the Foreign Resolution Action, creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not, by reason of being located in the ADGM, receive the same treatment, and have similar legal rights, as creditors (including depositors) who are located or payable in the non-ADGM jurisdiction concerned; or (e) recognition of, and taking action in support of, the Foreign Resolution Action (or the relevant part) would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM.

question: Under what conditions can an Issuer make an Exempt Offer to a limited number of Persons, and how does this relate to the admission of Securities on a Multilateral Trading Facility?
answer: An Issuer may direct an Exempt Offer to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients when seeking to admit its Securities to trading on a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF). This specific circumstance is outlined in the regulatory framework, allowing for such an offer under certain conditions. The Regulator prescribes that an Exempt Offer can be made to a limited number of Persons, provided these Persons are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties. This is applicable when the Securities are offered within a Private Financing Platform or via an MTF. Additionally, the Issuer may simultaneously make an Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, as permitted by the regulations. This dual approach allows Issuers to strategically target different categories of investors while complying with the regulatory requirements for Exempt Offers [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] and ensuring that the Securities are admitted to trading on an MTF as required [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42].
source_passage_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF. An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2). For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).
target_passage_text: For the purposes of section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, the Regulator prescribes the following to be circumstances in which an Offer is an Exempt Offer: (1) an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients; (2) an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period, excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons; (3) an Offer where the total consideration to be paid by a Person to acquire the Securities is at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (4) an Offer where the Securities are denominated in amounts of at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (5) an Offer where the total aggregate consideration for the Securities offered is less than $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency, calculated over a period of 12 months; (6) an Offer where Shares are issued in substitution for Shares of the same class as already issued, where the issue of the new Shares does not involve any increase in the issued Share capital; (7) an Offer where the Securities are Convertibles issued under a Prospectus to existing members or creditors of the Issuer or a member of its Group and there is no additional consideration to be paid; (8) an Offer where the Securities are offered in connection with a Takeover and a document is made available containing information which is considered by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (9) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a merger if a document is available containing information which is regarded by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (10) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue where: (a) the Securities are of a class subject to Reporting Entity disclosure; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Securities including rights attaching to those Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (11) an Offer where the Shares are offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Shareholders free of charge or dividends paid out in the form of Shares of the same class as the Shares in respect of which the dividends are paid, and a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Shares and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (12) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted to an existing or former Director or Employee, or any Close Relative of such a Director or Employee, of the Issuer or a member of the same Group as the Issuer and: (a) the Issuer or the member of the Group already has its Securities admitted to trading on a Regulated Exchange; and (b) a document is made available to the offerees containing information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; or (13) other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk, an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility.

question: What must an Insurer do about reinsurance recoveries and future claims payments?
answer: An Insurer must treat as an asset the value of reinsurance and other recoveries expected to be received for claims. At the same time, the Insurer must treat as a liability the value of future claims payments and the costs related to settling these claims, which arise from events that have already happened by the Solvency Reference Date. This means the Insurer needs to show both the money it expects to get back from reinsurance and the money it expects to pay out for claims in its financial records. This approach helps ensure that the Insurer's financial situation is clear and follows the rules. By doing this, the Insurer can accurately show both the expected income from reinsurance and the expected expenses for claims, keeping its financial reporting honest and transparent [#SRC:e6345a04-a9de-4dbf-8085-91eee4cffec6] and [#TGT:4232ff77-b15f-40cc-97ad-71bf51fe2853].
source_passage_text: An Insurer must treat as an asset the value of reinsurance and other recoveries expected to be received in respect of claims referred to in Rules 5.4.7 and 5.4.8 in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards.
target_passage_text: An Insurer must treat as a liability the value of future claims payments and associated direct and indirect settlement costs, arising from insured events that have occurred as at the Solvency Reference Date.

question: When a Payment Account Provider needs to figure out its Variable Capital Requirement, what steps should it follow to ensure it meets the highest Capital Requirement for its activities?
answer: To calculate its Variable Capital Requirement, a Payment Account Provider should add up specific percentages of its monthly payment volume: 2.5% of the first $10 million, 1% of the next $90 million, 0.5% of the next $150 million, and 0.25% of any remaining volume. This calculation helps determine the Variable Capital Requirement, which is one of the potential highest Capital Requirements the provider must meet. The provider must also consider other requirements like the Base Capital Requirement or the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, depending on the services it offers, such as currency exchange or money remittance. The highest requirement among these options is the one the provider must follow to comply with the regulations. This ensures that the provider is adequately capitalized for the financial services it offers [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] and [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4].
source_passage_text: Subject to Rule 3.6A.7, an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission enabling it to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services must calculate the Capital Requirement for each activity it undertakes as the highest of: (a) the applicable Base Capital Requirement as set out in Section 3.3; and (b) (i) where it undertakes currency exchange the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as set out in Section 3.7; (ii) for a Money Remitter: (A) the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as set out in Section 3.7; and (B) the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6A.2; (iii) for a Payment Account Provider the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6A.4; or (iv) for a Stored Value Provider the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6A.6.
target_passage_text: Payment Account Providers. A Payment Account Provider must calculate its Variable Capital Requirement as the sum of the following: (a) 2.5% of the first $10 million of monthly payment volume; (b) 1% of the next $90 million of monthly payment volume; (c) 0.5% of the next $150 million of monthly payment volume; and (d) 0.25% of any remaining monthly payment volume.

question: What steps does an Authorised Person need to take to calculate the RWA for Credit Risk Exposures, given the rules for credit assessments?
answer: To calculate the Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) for Credit Risk Exposures, an Authorised Person needs to follow a series of steps. First, they must determine the value of each Exposure, whether it's on the balance sheet or off, using the correct measurement methods. Then, they need to sort each Exposure into categories based on the rules. After that, they assign a Credit Quality Grade and risk weight to each Exposure. The RWA for each Exposure is calculated using a formula that multiplies the Exposure value by the risk weight. Finally, they add up all the RWA amounts for their Credit Risk Exposures. This process is part of the broader governance of credit assessments, which helps determine the Credit Risk Weight (CRW) for these Exposures [#SRC:dced9cf2-78fe-480a-9b65-4bff40564d27] and [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].
source_passage_text: This Section governs credit assessments of Exposures for the purpose of determining the CRW for Credit Risk (CR) Exposures as provided in Rule 4.8.3 and for securitisation (SE) Exposures as provided in Rule 4.8.4.
target_passage_text: Calculation of RWA for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures). To calculate its RWA for CR Exposures, an Authorised Person must: (a) calculate the value of the Exposure (represented as "E") for every on-balance sheet and every off balance sheet asset in accordance with the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM; (b) categorise that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.10; (c) allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade and risk weight for that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.11 and 4.12; (d) calculate the RWA amount for that Exposure using the following formula: RWA(CR) = E x CRW where: (i) "RWA(CR)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure; (ii) "E" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that CR Exposure; and (iii) "CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for that CR Exposure determined in accordance with (b) and (c); and (e) add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (d) for all its CR Exposures.

question: What must an MTF or OTF do if it doesn't use a Recognised Clearing House for spot commodities, and how is this similar to what a Recognised Investment Exchange must do when using a non-recognised clearing party?
answer: If an MTF or OTF doesn't use a Recognised Clearing House for spot commodities, it must provide the FSRA with satisfactory arrangements for using a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility (SCSF). These arrangements need to meet specific regulatory requirements, treating the SCSF similarly to a Recognised Clearing House. In a similar situation, if a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a clearing party that isn't a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it must confirm in writing to the Regulator the satisfactory arrangements made. This ensures both the MTF/OTF and the Recognised Investment Exchange follow the necessary rules when using alternative settlement options, keeping their operations compliant with the regulatory standards [#SRC:dd55d3d1-2eb7-4c91-ae7c-a494a1577f1c] and [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES Spot Commodity Settlement Facilities (SCSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.8.3, however, and in the context of Accepted Spot Commodities, an MTF/OTF must provide the FSRA the satisfactory arrangements made when such MTF or OTF does not engage a RCH (for example, to use in this context, when it has engaged, or proposing to engage, an SCSF). To clarify, the FSRA will require that arrangements to use an SCSF for settlement purposes will require the SCSF to comply with the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3 (with the references to a RCH being read as references to an SCSF).
target_passage_text: If a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, the Recognised Investment Exchange must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements made under Rule 3.8.1.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity is making disclosures, what must they include about their financial forecasts and Ore Reserves?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must include several important details in its disclosures about financial forecasts and Ore Reserves. For financial forecasts, the entity needs to list all significant economic assumptions, and if any are sensitive, they should explain why and how they determined these assumptions. They also need to mention the Production Target related to the forecast. For Ore Reserves, the entity must perform a Technical Study, like a feasibility study, to ensure confidence in the factors used for estimating reserves. The main assumptions and results of this study should be shared. This approach ensures that all necessary information is provided to understand both the financial and technical aspects of the entity's operations, as required [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464] and permitted [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_passage_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), in order to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, a Mining Reporting Entity will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study ). The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.

question: When can a Recognised Investment Exchange run a Multilateral Trading Facility, and what must be in its Recognition Order?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange can run a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) or an Organised Trading Facility (OTF) if its Recognition Order includes a specific permission for it. This permission is necessary for the exchange to legally operate these facilities. If the Recognition Order includes this permission, then the exchange must follow the rules for MTFs and OTFs as outlined in COBS. Additionally, if the exchange is using Virtual Assets in its MTF operations, it must also meet the Virtual Asset Framework requirements. This ensures that the exchange operates within the legal and regulatory boundaries set for these activities, maintaining compliance with all relevant rules [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] and [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].
source_passage_text: MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS Recognised Investment Exchanges Operating an MTF using Virtual Assets Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1, a Recognised Investment Exchange may operate an MTF, provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. MIR Rule 3.4.2 requires that where such a stipulation is granted to a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Recognised Investment Exchange must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework in relation to operation of an MTF (using Virtual Assets) while the remainder of its operations must be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. If it does include such a stipulation, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, but that function only.

question: Under what conditions must a Reporting Entity comply with the requirement to have audited financial statements when seeking admission to the Official List under the assets eligibility test?
answer: A Reporting Entity must comply with the requirement to have audited financial statements if it is seeking admission to the Official List under the assets eligibility test and has less than three years of such statements, as prescribed by the Regulator. The audited financial statements must cover a prior period of three years or a shorter period if deemed acceptable by the Regulator. These statements must be consolidated for the Applicant and its subsidiary undertakings, prepared in accordance with IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator, and audited according to the standards of the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board or other acceptable standards. This compliance is necessary to meet the Regulator's requirements for entities with less than three years of audited financial statements or when the Regulator considers quarterly cash reports necessary for other reasons, such as the admission of a cash-box [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] and [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1].
source_passage_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.
target_passage_text: Audited financial statements. An Applicant must have published or filed audited accounts which: (1) cover a prior period of three years or any other, shorter period acceptable to the Regulator; (2) are consolidated for the Applicant and any of its subsidiary undertakings; (3) have been prepared in accordance with IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator; and (4) have been audited and reported on by auditors in accordance with auditing standards of the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) or other standards acceptable to the Regulator.

question: When must Ancillary Stabilisation be undertaken in relation to the Stabilisation Window for Relevant Securities admitted to a Recognised Investment Exchange?
answer: Ancillary Stabilisation must be undertaken in accordance with specific conditions, including the timing of the Stabilisation Window. This window begins on the date when Relevant Securities are admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange and concludes no later than thirty days after this date. During this period, Relevant Securities may be over allotted only during the subscription period and at the Offer price. Additionally, the exercise period of the Greenshoe Option must align with the Stabilisation Window, ensuring that all actions are conducted within the specified timeframe. These requirements ensure that the stabilisation activities are properly timed and disclosed, maintaining market integrity and transparency [#SRC:a4e4d44f-4fae-4648-880f-1450a2b98fc4] and [#TGT:21eb4260-16a2-4970-990b-21d85832e1c0].
source_passage_text: Conditions for Ancillary Stabilisation Ancillary Stabilisation must be undertaken in accordance with Rule 6.2.8 and with the following: (1) Relevant Securities may be over allotted only during the subscription period and at the Offer price; (2) a position resulting from the exercise of an Overallotment Facility by a Reporting Entity which is not covered by the Greenshoe Option may not exceed 5% of the original Offer; (3) the Greenshoe Option may be exercised by the beneficiaries of such an option only where Relevant Securities have been over allotted; (4) the Greenshoe Option may not amount to more than 15% of the original Offer; (5) the exercise period of the Greenshoe Option must be the same as the Stabilisation Window required under Rule 6.2.8; and (6) the exercise of the Greenshoe Option must be disclosed to the public promptly, together with all appropriate details, including in particular the date of exercise and the number and nature of Relevant Securities involved.
target_passage_text: Time-related conditions for Price Stabilisation The period covered by the Stabilisation Window is the period beginning on the date of admission to trading of Relevant Securities on a Recognised Investment Exchange and ending no later than thirty (30) days thereafter.

question: Under what conditions must the Regulator refrain from disclosing a statement made during an interview conducted by an Investigator, and what procedural steps must the Investigator follow to require attendance at such an interview?
answer: The Regulator is prohibited from disclosing a statement made by a person during an interview conducted under specific legal provisions to any law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings unless the person consents or disclosure is mandated by law or court order. This confidentiality obligation underscores the importance of protecting the rights of individuals involved in investigations. Concurrently, the Investigator has the authority to compel the Person Under Investigation or any other relevant individual to attend an interview at a specified time and place. This is achieved through a written notice that mandates attendance and the answering of questions. The Investigator's procedural powers extend to requiring the production of documents, provision of information, and assistance, as well as permitting entry to business premises for document inspection and copying. These procedural steps ensure that the investigation is thorough and compliant with legal standards, while the confidentiality prohibition safeguards the integrity of the investigative process [#SRC:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6] and [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
source_passage_text: In addition to the overriding duty of confidentiality set out in section 198, section 207(2) of the FSMR prohibits the Regulator from disclosing a statement made by a person to an investigator at an interview conducted pursuant to section 206(1)(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against that person unless: (a) the person consents to the disclosure; or (b) the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_passage_text: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to— (a) attend an interview at a Specified time and place and answer questions; (b) produce at a Specified time and place any Specified Documents or Documents of a Specified description; (c) provide such information as the Investigator may require; (d) provide such assistance as the Investigator may require; or (e) permit the Investigator to enter the business premises of such person during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on such premises.

question: When do Units have to be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and when is the usual rule against this not applied?
answer: Units in a class of Securities must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange. However, the usual rule against this does not apply in some cases. These include when the Units make up less than 10% of the same class already traded, when they are issued as replacements without increasing capital, or when they are given to current Unitholders for free or as dividends, as long as they are the same class and come with information about the Offer. Also, Units already traded on another Recognised or Regulated Exchange can be exempt if they have been traded for more than 18 months, meet ongoing obligations, and have a summary document approved by the Regulator. These exceptions allow certain offers to go ahead without the usual rule, while still needing to be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab] and [#TGT:3a7c96c9-65c9-422f-b480-4592229e0ace].
source_passage_text: Exempt Offers in respect of Units. All Units in a class of Securities admitted to trading including those specified under Rule 3.3.5 must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange.
target_passage_text: Exempt Offers in respect of Units. The prohibition in section 61 of the FSMR does not apply, subject to the requirement in Rule 3.3.6, to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of: (1) Units representing, over a period of 12 months, less than 10% of the number of Units of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; (2) Units issued in substitution for Units of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange, if the issue of Units does not involve any increase in the issued capital; (3) Units offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Unitholders free of charge, or in respect of dividends paid out in the form of Units of the same class as the Units in respect of which the dividends are paid, if: (a) the Units are of the same class as the Units already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Units and the reasons for and details of the Offer; or (4) Units already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange (the "Other Market"), where: (a) the Units of the same class have been admitted to trading and continuously traded on the Other Market for more than 18 months; (b) the on-going obligations for trading on that Other Market have been complied with; and (c) there is a summary document in the English language approved by the Regulator and published: (i) containing the Key Information required under Rule 4.5.2(1)(b); (ii) stating where the most recent and current Prospectus, if any, can be obtained; and (iii) specifying where the financial information published by the Issuer pursuant to its on-going disclosure obligations of the Other Market is available.

question: How must a Recognised Clearing House use the most recent audited information when calculating capital requirements for operational risks and other specified risks?
answer: A Recognised Clearing House is required to use the most recent audited information from its annual financial statement when calculating capital requirements. This includes ensuring that operational expenses are aligned with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as part of the procedure. The capital requirements must cover various risks, including winding down or restructuring activities, operational risks, credit and counterparty credit risks, market risks, and business risks. Specifically, for operational risks, the Recognised Clearing House must calculate its capital requirement using either the Basic Indicator Approach or, with prior authorisation, the Standardised or Alternative Standardised Approach. Additionally, for credit and counterparty credit risks, the capital requirements are calculated as a percentage of risk-weighted exposure amounts, with specific risk weights applied to exposures related to other clearing houses. The business risk capital requirement must be based on an approved estimate of potential losses from adverse scenarios, subject to a minimum threshold. This comprehensive approach ensures that the Recognised Clearing House maintains sufficient capital to cover these risks as required [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b] and permitted [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0].
source_passage_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.2.1, Recognised Clearing Houses shall use the most recent audited information from their annual financial statement and operational expenses shall be considered in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).
target_passage_text: A Recognised Clearing House shall hold capital more than or equal to the sum of capital calculated in respect of the following risks. (a) Winding down or restructuring activities. Six months' gross operational expenses. (b) Operational risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirement for operational risks using either the Basic Indicator Approach or, with prior authorisation from the Regulator, the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, both as provided specifically in Appendix 7.3 and generally in Appendix 7 of PRU. (c) Credit, counterparty credit and market risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirements as the sum of 10% of its risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit and counterparty credit risk and its capital requirements for market risk calculated in accordance with Appendix 6 of PRU, subject to the following. (i) For the calculation of the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and counterparty credit risk, a Recognised Clearing House shall apply the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) method in section 4.8 of PRU. (ii) Where a Recognised Clearing House does not use its own resources, the Recognised Clearing House shall apply a risk weight of 250% to its exposure stemming from any contributions to the default fund of another Clearing house and a risk weight of 2% to any trade exposures with another Clearing house. (d) Business risk. A Recognised Clearing House shall submit to the Regulator for approval its own estimate of the capital necessary to cover losses resulting from business risk based on reasonably foreseeable adverse scenarios relevant to its business model. The capital requirement for business risk shall be equal to the approved estimate and shall be subject to a minimum amount of 25% of its annual gross operational expenses.

question: Under what circumstances must an Insider not disclose Inside Information to another person, considering both the necessary course of business and the proper exercise of duties?
answer: An Insider must not disclose Inside Information to another person unless the disclosure is made in the necessary course of business, which aligns with the Insider's employment, office, profession, or duties. This means that any disclosure outside these parameters is prohibited. Specifically, the prohibition applies when the disclosure occurs outside the proper course of exercising one's employment, profession, or duties. Therefore, Insiders must ensure that any sharing of Inside Information is strictly within the scope of their professional responsibilities and necessary business activities. This dual requirement ensures that Inside Information is protected from unauthorized dissemination, maintaining the integrity of sensitive information and compliance with regulatory standards [#SRC:ecc61e9a-8e78-4813-b5ee-b57fdb74268a] and [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b].
source_passage_text: Disclosure "in the necessary course of business". Section 92(3) does not prohibit the disclosure of Inside Information by an Insider to another person if the disclosure is made in accordance with the Insider's employment, office, profession or duties.
target_passage_text: The second is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.

question: What does it mean when an Insider deals or tries to deal in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset, or Accepted Spot Commodity based on Inside Information?
answer: When an Insider deals or tries to deal in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset, or Accepted Spot Commodity based on Inside Information, it means that the Inside Information is either the reason for or has a big influence on their decision to make the deal. This is important because it defines the first type of Behaviour where an Insider uses Inside Information to guide their actions in the market. The Regulator sees this as a key factor in deciding if the dealing is 'on the basis' of Inside Information. This understanding helps ensure that Insiders do not misuse privileged information to gain an unfair advantage in financial markets, maintaining fairness and integrity in trading activities [#SRC:09923519-864f-48a7-a123-52dfa0a02c05] and [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25].
source_passage_text: Factors to be taken into account "on the basis of". To contravene section 92(2), it is necessary that the Insider deals or attempts to deal "on the basis" of Inside Information. In the Regulator's view, if the Inside Information is the reason for, or a material influence on, the decision to deal or attempt to deal then this indicates that the dealing or attempt to deal is "on the basis" of the Inside Information.
target_passage_text: The first type of Behaviour is where an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity on the basis of Inside Information relating to the Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities in question.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, what obligations must it fulfill in its Summary of Reserves and Resources if these estimates have not been verified as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves according to a Mining Reporting Standard?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation must adhere to specific obligations if these estimates have not been verified as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard. The entity is required to include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources the steps taken to evaluate the previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates, the status of any further evaluation or exploration work needed, and the proposed source of funding for such activities. Additionally, if more than three years have passed since the initial disclosure and the estimates remain unverified, the entity must provide an explanation for the delay and outline its intentions, proposed timetable, and funding plans for verifying and disclosing the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves. These requirements ensure transparency and accountability in the reporting of mineral estimates, aligning with the broader regulatory framework that governs such disclosures [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907].
source_passage_text: Where a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation the Mining Reporting Entity does not need to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1) provided the Mining Reporting Entity complies with: (1) Rule 11.7.2; (2) Rule 11.7.3; (3) Rule 11.7.4; and (4) Rule 11.7.6.
target_passage_text: Non-Equivalent Estimates – Summary of Reserves and Resources. If a Mining Reporting Entity has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates compliance with Rule 11.7.3 which have not subsequently been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, then: (1) the Mining Reporting Entity must disclose in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, the: (a) steps it has taken in evaluating the previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates; (b) status of any further evaluation and/or exploration work required to verify and disclose the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with the Mining Reporting Standard; and (c) status of the proposed source of funding for the evaluation and/or exploration work referred to in Rule 11.7.6(1)(b); and (2) if it has been more than three years since the first disclosure of the Non-Equivalent Estimates under Rule 11.7.4 and those estimates have not been subsequently verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, then the Mining Reporting Entity must disclose in its Summary of Reserves and Resources: (a) an explanation of why the Non-Equivalent Estimates have not been verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and (b) the Mining Reporting Entity’s intention, proposed timetable and proposed source of funding with regard to verifying and disclosing the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard.

question: When should a trader not try to control the market by holding too much of a commodity or bonds, especially if it might mislead others about prices or supply?
answer: A trader should not try to control the market by holding too much of a commodity or bonds if doing so might mislead others about prices or supply. This is important when a trader builds a large position in something like crude oil and doesn't offer it back to the market at fair rates. Such actions can lead to unusual price changes and corner the market. Similarly, if a trader with a long position in bond futures buys a lot of bonds and doesn't lend them out, it can make prices go up unfairly. These actions are not allowed because they can create false impressions about the market and set prices at unnatural levels, which is against the rules [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] and [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f].
source_passage_text: Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b): (a) during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract. The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate. The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market. His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and (b) a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market. His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_passage_text: The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which— (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or (b) secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: When can the Regulator stop an auditor or actuary from working with an Authorised Person or Recognised Body, and what steps do they follow?
answer: The Regulator can stop an auditor or actuary from working with an Authorised Person or Recognised Body if they find that the auditor or actuary has broken the rules. To decide this, the Regulator looks at how serious the rule-breaking is, whether it has hurt customers, and if it has harmed the ADGM's reputation. They also check if the rule-breaking has made it more likely for financial crime to happen. The Regulator will see if the auditor or actuary has tried to fix the problem and if any professional bodies have already punished them. They also look at the auditor's or actuary's past behavior and any past punishments. If these checks show that the rule-breaking is serious, the Regulator may decide to stop them from working with any Authorised Person, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity, or any specific group of them, as required [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] and permitted [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
source_passage_text: In deciding whether to exercise our power to disqualify an auditor or actuary under section 233(3) of FSMR, and what the scope of any disqualification will be, we will take into account all the circumstances of the case, including: (a) the nature and seriousness of any contravention of FSMR or Rules and the effect of that contravention; (b) whether any contravention of FSMR or Rules, or any failure to disclose information to us, has resulted in or is likely to result in: (i) loss to customers; (ii) damage to the reputation of the ADGM; or (iii) an increased risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity may be used for the purposes of financial crime; (c) any action taken by the auditor or actuary to remedy the contravention; (d) any disciplinary action taken (or to be taken) against the auditor or actuary by a relevant professional body, and whether that action adequately addresses the particular contravention; and (e) the previous compliance record of the auditor or actuary concerned, and whether the relevant regulatory body or professional body has imposed any previous disciplinary sanctions that may be relevant.
target_passage_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: Under what circumstances must P not make a statement or conceal facts to avoid committing an offence or contravention, particularly when inducing actions related to Relevant Agreements or Designated Investments?
answer: P must not make a statement or conceal facts if doing so is intended to induce, or is reckless as to whether it may induce, another person to engage in specific financial activities. In the context of the FSMR, this includes entering into, offering to enter into, or refraining from entering or offering to enter into a Relevant Agreement, or exercising or refraining from exercising rights conferred by a Designated Investment. Similarly, under the Regulations, P commits a contravention if the statement or concealment is intended to induce, or is reckless as to whether it may induce, another person to enter into, offer to enter into, refrain from entering or offering to enter into, or to acquire, dispose of, subscribe for, underwrite, or refrain from acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for, or underwriting a Financial Instrument, Specified Investment, Accepted Virtual Asset, or Accepted Spot Commodity. Both contexts emphasize the prohibition against misleading actions that could influence another's financial decisions [#SRC:ccc1bc69-f5cb-4668-a23b-63b9c972177a] and [#TGT:bd2fec86-0605-4dc6-a24c-4e076626ca58].
source_passage_text: Section 102(2) of the FSMR. Section 102(2) of the FSMR provides that a person ("P"): "...commits an offence if P makes the statement or conceals the facts with the intention of inducing, or is reckless as to whether making it or concealing them may induce, another person (whether or not the person to whom the statement is made)- (a) to enter into or Offer to enter into, or to refrain from entering or Offering to enter into, a Relevant Agreement, or (b) to exercise, or refrain from exercising, any rights conferred by a Designated Investment."
target_passage_text: P commits a contravention of these Regulations if P makes the statement or conceals the facts with the intention of inducing, or is reckless as to whether making it or concealing them may induce, another person (whether or not the person to whom the statement is made) — (a) to enter into or offer to enter into, or to refrain from entering or offering to enter into; or (b) to acquire, dispose of, subscribe for or underwrite, or refrain from acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for or underwriting; or (c) to exercise, or refrain from exercising, any rights conferred by – a Financial Instrument, a Specified Investment, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity, as applicable.

question: While a Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund is exempt from many detailed requirements applicable to Public Funds, what obligations must it fulfill in managing the Fund and its Property according to the Fund's Constitution and Prospectus?
answer: A Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund, despite being exempt from many detailed requirements applicable to Public Funds, must still adhere to several key obligations. Specifically, the Fund Manager is required to manage the Fund and its Property in strict accordance with the Fund's Constitution and its most recent Prospectus. Additionally, the Fund Manager must perform the functions conferred upon it by the Fund's Constitution and comply with any conditions or restrictions imposed by the Regulator, including those related to its Financial Services Permission. Furthermore, the Fund Manager is obligated to adhere to any requirements or limitations imposed under the applicable Rules, such as limits on financial interests held by the Fund Manager or its associates in the Fund. These obligations ensure that the Fund Manager operates within the regulatory framework while managing a Qualified Investor Fund [#SRC:8258f9f2-c4ef-42b0-9226-99d2db70344e] and [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b].
source_passage_text: While a Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund is exempt from many of the detailed requirements applicable to Public Funds and Exempt Funds, it will continue to be subject to most of the main obligations of Fund Managers. Therefore, such a Fund Manager should be mindful that when managing a Qualified Investor Fund, it is subject to some of the overarching obligations applicable to Fund Managers, particularly: (a) Rule 12.2 (Fund Manager and Trustee general duties and functions); (b) GEN Section 2.2 (The Principles for Authorised Persons); and (c) GEN Chapter 3 (Management, Systems and Controls).
target_passage_text: A Fund Manager shall: (a) manage the Fund including the Fund Property in accordance with the Fund's Constitution and its most recent Prospectus; (b) perform the functions conferred on it by the Fund's Constitution and by or under these Rules; (c) comply with any conditions or restrictions imposed by the Regulator including those on its Financial Services Permission or in respect of the Fund; and (d) comply with any requirements or limitations imposed under these Rules including any limits relating to financial interests it or any of its associates may hold in a Fund, for which it acts as the appointed Fund Manager.

question: What must an Applicant do to meet the working capital statement requirement when seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, considering both the general eligibility requirements and the specific provisions for Digital Securities?
answer: An Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List must satisfy the Regulator that it and any Subsidiaries have sufficient working capital available for its present requirements or, if not, how it proposes to provide the additional working capital needed. This requirement is part of the general eligibility criteria that must be met, as outlined in the Listing Rules. Specifically, for Digital Securities, the FSRA expects compliance with the working capital statement requirement, along with other eligibility requirements. The FSRA also has the discretion to require the appointment of a Sponsor or other expert adviser due to the complexities involved in Digital Securities. Therefore, an Applicant must ensure that it addresses both the working capital needs and any additional requirements set by the FSRA for Digital Securities, including potentially appointing a Sponsor to assist in meeting these obligations [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] and permitted [#SRC:e4b331b0-8437-43a6-8fa7-a77f476e8c3a].
source_passage_text: MARKETS RULES LISTING RULES As set out earlier in paragraph 5, it is the FSRAs general expectation that its Regulations (FSMR) and Rules be read as written, including in relation to the Listing Rules (Chapter 2 of MKT). In relation to specific Listing Rules: a) an Issuer seeking to issue Digital Securities should note that the listing principles set out in MKT Rule 2.2 apply in full; b) for the avoidance of doubt, the requirement for a working capital statement per MKT Rule 2.3.3 applies, along with the other general eligibility requirements of MKT Rule 2.3; c) pursuant to Chapter 5 of MKT, the FSRA has discretion to require the appointment by an Issuer of a Sponsor, compliance adviser or other expert adviser. Due to the complexities involved and the relative infancy of Digital Securities, the FSRA will generally expect an Issuer of Digital Securities to appoint a Sponsor as required by MKT Rule 5.1.2; and d) for Digital Securities in the form of Units of a Fund, Chapter 3 (instead of Chapter 2) of MKT contains the relevant Listing Rules.
target_passage_text: Working capital. An Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List must satisfy the Regulator that it and any Subsidiaries have sufficient working capital available for its present requirements or, if not, how it proposes to provide the additional working capital needed.

question: How must a Listed Entity calculate the number of Equity Securities it may issue under the procedural requirements, and what restrictions apply to prevent issuing more than allowed without Ordinary Securities holders' approval?
answer: A Listed Entity must adhere to specific procedural requirements when calculating the number of Equity Securities it may issue. This involves counting each fully paid Ordinary Security as one, each partly paid Security as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it can become, and each Convertible Security similarly. In other cases, the Regulator will decide the count to ensure voting opportunities for holders of Ordinary Securities. However, the entity is prohibited from issuing or agreeing to issue more Equity Securities than calculated by a specific formula without the approval of Ordinary Securities holders. This formula considers 20% of the Base Amount, which includes fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the previous 12 months, adjusted for exceptions and approvals, minus Relevant Issues. These restrictions ensure that the issuance does not exceed the calculated maximum without necessary approvals, maintaining the integrity of the issuance process [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] and [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
source_passage_text: Requirements applicable to new issues under Rule 9.7.1 . In calculating the number of Equity Securities that a Listed Entity may issue or agree to issue under Rule 9.7.1 (including the number contributing to Relevant Issues), unless the Regulator determines otherwise, the following must be applied: (1) each fully paid Ordinary Security is counted as one; (2) each partly paid Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up; (3) each Convertible Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted; and (4) in any other case, each Security is counted as the Regulator may decide, having regard to the need to ensure that holders of Ordinary Securities have an opportunity to vote on issues that may dilute their holdings or the characteristics of the Security.
target_passage_text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. (4) partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement, but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement. Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than: (a) with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or (b) under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: What actions must an Authorised Person take regarding the most recent reconciliations of Client Money to ensure compliance with both the Resolution Pack requirements and monthly reconciliation obligations with Third Party Agents?
answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain the most recent reconciliations of Client Money as part of their Resolution Pack, ensuring these records are up-to-date and comprehensive. This involves reconciling their records of Client Accounts with the monthly statements received from Third Party Agents at least once every calendar month. This dual obligation ensures that the Authorised Person not only keeps accurate and current records of Client Money but also aligns these records with external confirmations from Third Party Agents. By doing so, the Authorised Person fulfills the regulatory requirement to include these reconciliations in the Resolution Pack, thereby demonstrating compliance with both internal and external reconciliation standards. This process is crucial for maintaining the integrity and accuracy of financial records related to Client Money, which is essential for regulatory compliance and financial transparency [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] and [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6].
source_passage_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and 15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule 15.4.4 and Rule 15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule 15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and 15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must: (a) at least every calendar month, reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents with monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents; (b) at least every six months, count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person, or its Nominee Company, and reconcile the result of that count to the records of the Authorised Person; and (c) at least every six months, reconcile individual Client ledger balances with the Authorised Person's records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts.

question: If a Benchmark Administrator is also the market operator for a Specified Benchmark, what must they do to ensure they meet the rules and practice standards?
answer: When a Benchmark Administrator is also the operator of the market from which a Specified Benchmark is determined, they must create rules and practice standards for the benchmark they manage. These standards should clearly define the roles and responsibilities of those providing benchmark information, including those outside the ADGM, and the Administrator itself. The Administrator can include these standards in the market's rules, but this must not interfere with their ability to meet regulatory requirements [#TGT:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac] and is allowed under specific conditions [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28].
source_passage_text: Where: (a) a Specified Benchmark is determined solely on the basis of information obtained from a market operated by a Recognised Body, a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility; and (b) the Benchmark Administrator for that Specified Benchmark is also that Recognised Body, Multilateral Trading Facility, or Organised Trading Facility; (c) the Benchmark Administrator may choose to incorporate the rules and practice standards required under Rule 21.3.5 into the rules of that Recognised Body, Multilateral Trading Facility, or Organised Trading Facility, provided that this does not affect the Benchmark Administrators ability to comply with its regulatory obligations.
target_passage_text: Benchmark Administrator rules and practice standards The Benchmark Administrator must: (a) in relation to the Specified Benchmark it administers, develop rules and practice standards which set out the responsibilities, including those applicable under the Rules for: (i) Specified Benchmark Information Providers; (ii) other Persons providing information in relation to a Specified Benchmark from outside the ADGM; and (iii) the Benchmark Administrator;

question: What documents must an Applicant submit to the Regulator for a listing application, and what additional steps are required to complete the application process?
answer: For a listing application, an Applicant must submit all documents specified in the relevant rules to the Regulator at the designated address. This includes the documents outlined in Rule 2.4.1, which are essential for the application process. Additionally, the Applicant is required to submit these documents in the final form as prescribed by the Regulator. The process also involves paying the applicable fee as detailed in the FEES Rulebook at the time of submitting the completed application form. Furthermore, the Applicant must provide any additional documents, explanations, and information that the Regulator may require, including those specified in Rules 2.4.4 and 2.4.5. Verification of any submitted information must also be provided in the manner specified by the Regulator. These steps ensure that the application is complete and meets all regulatory requirements [#SRC:0cd75f80-4564-41c1-aa7d-5303022d6e69] and [#TGT:51448452-8fa0-4ada-97cb-b76691244d25].
source_passage_text: Listing application. All the documents in Rule 2.4.1 must be submitted to the Regulator at the Regulator's address.
target_passage_text: Listing application. An Applicant must apply to the Regulator by: (1) submitting in final form the relevant documents in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe; (2) paying the fee set out in the FEES Rulebook at the time of submission of the completed application form; (3) submitting all additional documents, explanations and information as may be required by the Regulator, including the documents specified in Rules 2.4.4 and 2.4.5; and (4) submitting verification of any information in such manner as the Regulator may specify.

question: How must an Authorised Person identify its capital instruments for inclusion in Available Stable Funding, considering the eligibility requirements and the calculation of residual maturity?
answer: An Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments for inclusion in Available Stable Funding by considering the eligibility requirements under specific rules, ensuring that the capital elements meet these criteria. This process excludes Tier 2 capital instruments with a residual maturity of less than one year. Concurrently, the Authorised Person must determine the residual maturity of each instrument or liability to be included in the Available Stable Funding. This involves calculating the period up to the earliest point at which an investor can exercise their right to redeem their investment or withdraw the funding source. This dual approach ensures that only eligible and appropriately matured instruments are considered, aligning with the regulatory requirements for Available Stable Funding [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] and [#TGT:68a2eabe-76b5-4a9c-8bad-d8c20fd492aa].
source_passage_text: Available Stable Funding (ASF). Subject to Rule A10.4.6, an Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments that are to be included in its Available Stable Funding by considering the capital elements that are meet the requirements for eligibility under: (a) Rule 3.10.2; (b) Rule 3.11.2; and (c) Rule 3.12.2, excluding all Tier 2 capital instruments with residual maturity of less than one year.
target_passage_text: Available Stable Funding (ASF). In determining the residual maturity of an instrument captured under Rule A10.4.2 or Rule A10.4.3 or any other liability that is to be included in the Available Stable Funding, an Authorised Person must calculate the residual maturity of each instrument or liability as being that period up to the earliest point in time at which an investor has the right to exercise their right to redeem their investment or withdraw that source of funding.

question: When can the Regulator start looking into the business of an Authorised Person or Recognised Body, and how do requests from outside regulators fit into this?
answer: The Regulator can start an investigation into the business of an Authorised Person or Recognised Body if there is a good reason to do so. This includes looking into how the business is run, specific parts of the business, or who owns or controls it. The Regulator can also investigate if another regulator from outside the ADGM asks them to, as long as the request is made under the right section. This means the Regulator can check on businesses both because of their own concerns and because of requests from other regulators [#SRC:c12ad91e-5b46-46c8-aa05-fd73299e8675] and [#TGT:9c4e6686-4ca1-4a0e-b3b6-7488a81c9c2c].
source_passage_text: Under section 205(1) of FSMR the Regulator is empowered to commence an investigation if it appears there is good reason for doing so, into: (a) the nature, conduct or state of the Business of an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Remote Body; (b) a particular aspect of that Business; (c) the ownership or control of an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Remote Body; or (d) a matter reasonably requested to be investigated pursuant to a request by a Non-ADGM Regulator under section 217 of FSMR.
target_passage_text: If it appears to the Regulator that there is good reason for doing so, the Regulator may commence an investigation into— (a) the nature, conduct or state of the Business of an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Remote Body; (b) a particular aspect of that Business; (c) the ownership or control of an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Remote Body; or (d) a matter reasonably requested to be investigated pursuant to a request made under section ‎217.

question: When can a Payment Service User and Provider agree that some rules, like those about withdrawing consent, don't apply?
answer: A Payment Service User, if not a Natural Person, and a Payment Service Provider can agree in writing that certain rules, including those about withdrawing consent, don't apply to them. This means they can decide not to follow rules about charges for information, evidence on authentication, and liability for unauthorized transactions, among others. Specifically, they can agree not to follow Rule 19.10.1, which deals with withdrawing consent. However, the Payer can still withdraw consent for a Payment Transaction anytime before the Payment Order can't be revoked anymore, as stated in Rule 19.14.3. This agreement gives them the flexibility to decide which rules they want to follow, making it easier to manage their specific needs and situations [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] and [#TGT:31fb705e-a65c-4024-99d4-fadfe13f8f32].
source_passage_text: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (charges for information); (b) Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4) (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 19.18.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (d) Rule 19.20.1 (Payer or Payees liability for unauthorised transactions); (e) Rules 19.17.1 and 19.17.2 (requests for refund); (f) Rule 19.14.3 (revocation of a Payment Order); (g) Rule 19.21.2 (defective execution of Payer-initiated transactions); (h) Rule 19.21.3 (defective execution of Payee-initiated transactions); (i) Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1.
target_passage_text: Consent and withdrawal of consent. The Payer may withdraw its consent to an individual Payment Transaction at any time before the point at which the Payment Order can no longer be revoked under Rule 19.14.3.

question: When must a Listed Entity not issue Equity Securities without getting approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities, considering both the need for approval and the formula for calculating new issues?
answer: A Listed Entity must not issue Equity Securities without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities if the issuance is based on a conditional agreement requiring such approval. Additionally, the entity cannot issue more Equity Securities than allowed by a specific formula unless they get approval. This formula calculates the maximum number of Equity Securities that can be issued by considering the Base Amount, which includes all fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the last 12 months, and subtracts any Relevant Issues that were issued without approval. The Base Amount also includes exceptions and approvals under certain rules. Therefore, the entity must follow both the conditional agreement and the formula to ensure they do not issue Equity Securities without the necessary approval [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] and [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
source_passage_text: An agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entitys Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made. If a Listed Entity relies on this exception, it must not issue the Equity Securities without such approval.
target_passage_text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. (4) partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement, but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement. Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than: (a) with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or (b) under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security, and what information must an Issuer provide to the FSRA to facilitate this determination?
answer: The Regulator has the authority to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security through a written notice, provided it considers the terms and conditions appropriate. This power is exercised without limiting its general powers and is subject to the specific regulatory framework. For the FSRA to make such a determination, an Issuer must provide sufficient information to demonstrate that the proposed Digital Security meets the requirements of a Security as defined in the FSMR. This involves submitting an Approved Prospectus or Exempt Offer documentation, depending on the circumstances. The FSRA will use these documents to assess whether the Digital Security can be deemed a Security under the relevant section of FSMR. This process ensures that the Issuer complies with the necessary regulatory requirements and that the Regulator's decision is informed by comprehensive and accurate information [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY TREATMENT OF DIGITAL SECURITIES To use its powers under Section 58(2)(b), the FSRA expects that an Issuer will provide to it such information as is required to demonstrate that the proposed Digital Security meets the requirements of a Security (as defined in FSMR). In circumstances: a) requiring the submission of an Approved Prospectus to the FSRA, the FSRA will use the documentation submitted as part of this approval process to determine whether it will deem a Digital Security a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR; or b) relating to an Exempt Offer, the FSRA will review the Exempt Offer documentation for the purposes of being able to make a determination under Section 58(2)(b). The FSRAs review will not be for the purposes of approving the Exempt Offer itself.
target_passage_text: Without limiting the generality of its powers, the Regulator may, by written notice— (a) exclude the application of any requirements; or (b) deem any investment which is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of these Regulations and the Rules made under these Regulations; subject to such terms and conditions as it may consider appropriate.
