question: How does an Authorised Person get FSRA approval to use a new Virtual Asset, and what does the Regulator check to see if it qualifies as an Accepted Virtual Asset?
answer: To get FSRA approval for a new Virtual Asset, an Authorised Person must apply in writing, providing all necessary details about the asset and how they plan to manage its risks. The FSRA will then check if the Virtual Asset meets the standards to be an Accepted Virtual Asset. This includes looking at its maturity or market capitalisation and other important factors. The FSRA will inform the Authorised Person of their decision after reviewing these aspects. This process ensures that only suitable Virtual Assets are used in regulated activities [#SRC:ee620070-0c48-454c-9530-0b3abf34c142] [#TGT:223a987c-f08a-4402-8d01-2472978dd1e8].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS FOR AUTHORISED PERSONS ENGAGED IN REGULATED ACTIVITIES IN RELATION TO VIRTUAL ASSETS Accepted Virtual Assets An Authorised Person wishing to use a Virtual Asset(s) additional to the Accepted Virtual Asset(s) originally approved as part of its application process, must first seek the FSRAs approval before offering it to Clients. This application should be made in writing and include all relevant information relating to the use of the Virtual Asset, including the relevant controls the Authorised Person has in place (or if not already in place, that it proposes to implement), in order to manage any risks specific to the Virtual Asset. In forming a view on the suitability of the proposed Virtual Asset(s), the FSRA will take into account whether the proposed Virtual Asset meets the requirements to be an Accepted Virtual Asset, as set out in COBS Rule 17.2.2 and paragraph 25 of this Guidance. The FSRA will notify the Authorised Person of its determination.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of determining whether, in its opinion, a Virtual Asset meets the requirements of being an Accepted Virtual Asset, the Regulator will consider – (a) a maturity/market capitalisation threshold in respect of a Virtual Asset; and (b) other factors that, in the opinion of the Regulator, are to be taken into account in determining whether or not a Virtual Asset meets the requirements to be considered appropriate for the purpose of an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets.

question: What should an Authorised Person do about the approval process for new products and the risks involved?
answer: An Authorised Person must make sure that its Operational Risk policy includes a process for approving all new products, activities, processes, and systems. This is important because the Authorised Person also needs to identify and assess the Operational Risks that come with these new initiatives. The policy should help employees understand these risks clearly. Additionally, the Authorised Person must track any Operational Risk events and their financial impacts in a way that matches the types described in the Basel III framework. This means that the approval process is not just about getting new things started but also about understanding and managing the risks they bring. By doing this, the Authorised Person can better protect its operations and meet regulatory requirements [#SRC:1af2c43c-aa79-4dbc-af29-f41f395434a2] and [#TGT:d260ee65-4db8-4608-abfd-17a444410052].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person must ensure that its Operational Risk policy in Rule 6.2.1: (a) includes an approval process for all new products, activities, processes and systems; and (b) incorporates the requirement in Rule 6.3.1(a).
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must: (a) ensure that it identifies and assesses the Operational Risks inherent in all the Authorised Person's products, activities, processes and systems; (b) ensure the inherent risks in (a) are understood by relevant Employees of the Authorised Person; (c) systematically track Operational Risk events and any financial impact associated with such events; and (d) ensure that the tracking in (c) is consistent with the Operational Risk event types described in the Basel III framework.

question: What must an Authorised Person ensure when using an internal model for calculating Market Risk Capital Requirement, and under what conditions may they use such a model?
answer: An Authorised Person must have a rigorous and comprehensive stress testing programme in place when using an internal model, as required [#SRC:2c6f771c-32bd-4715-a834-56686269ef59]. Additionally, an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, or 5 may use an internal model to calculate its Market Risk Capital Requirement or its components if the model has received written approval from the Regulator [#TGT:2baf0f2f-b76e-4a58-bce0-9cf53cd900de].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person which uses an internal model in accordance with Rule 5.11.1 must have in place a rigorous and comprehensive stress testing programme which meets the criteria set out in Rule A6.9.4.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 may use an internal model to calculate its Market Risk Capital Requirement or any components of its Market Risk Capital Requirement if the use of such internally developed models has been approved in writing by the Regulator.

question: When does a Third Party Provider have to make sure a Customer isn't responsible for losses from unauthorised transactions, based on rules about Personalised Security Credentials?
answer: A Third Party Provider has to make sure that Customers can always report if their Personalised Security Credentials are lost, stolen, misused, or used without permission. This is important because if the Provider doesn't have a way for Customers to report these issues, the Customer won't be responsible for any losses from unauthorised transactions. However, this protection for the Customer only applies if they haven't acted fraudulently or been very careless in protecting their credentials. So, it's crucial for the Third Party Provider to have a reliable system for Customers to report problems, ensuring that the Customer isn't unfairly blamed for losses due to the Provider's failure to offer proper notification methods [#SRC:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90] [#TGT:d8fc441e-0a9e-4a18-bbd8-2cfe0dd0ee07].
source_passage_text: Customers liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Except where the Customer has acted fraudulently or has with intent or gross negligence failed to ensure that its Personalised Security Credentials are not accessible to persons other than the Customer, the Customer is not liable for any losses incurred in respect of an unauthorised Third Party Transaction: (a) arising after notification to the Third Party Provider in the agreed manner on becoming aware of the loss, theft, misappropriation or unauthorised use of the Customers Personalised Security Credentials; (b) where the Third Party Provider has failed at any time to provide, in accordance with Rule 20.9.2, appropriate means for notification; or (c) where the Third Party Provider has failed to apply Strong Customer Authentication.
target_passage_text: Personalised Security Credentials. A Third Party Provider must ensure that appropriate means are available at all times to enable a Customer to notify the Third Party Provider of the loss, theft, misappropriation or unauthorised use of the Customer’s Personalised Security Credentials.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has shared material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, what must it do in its Summary of Reserves and Resources if these estimates aren't yet confirmed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves?
answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity shares material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it must follow certain steps if these estimates haven't been confirmed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves. The entity needs to report in its Summary of Reserves and Resources the actions it has taken to evaluate these estimates, the current status of any additional work needed, and how it plans to fund this work. If more than three years have passed since the first disclosure and the estimates still aren't verified, the entity must explain why and share its plans, timeline, and funding sources for verifying these estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves. These steps are important to ensure that the entity is transparent about its progress and intentions regarding the mineral estimates it has disclosed [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907].
source_passage_text: Where a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation the Mining Reporting Entity does not need to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1) provided the Mining Reporting Entity complies with: (1) Rule 11.7.2; (2) Rule 11.7.3; (3) Rule 11.7.4; and (4) Rule 11.7.6.
target_passage_text: Non-Equivalent Estimates – Summary of Reserves and Resources. If a Mining Reporting Entity has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates compliance with Rule 11.7.3 which have not subsequently been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, then: (1) the Mining Reporting Entity must disclose in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, the: (a) steps it has taken in evaluating the previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates; (b) status of any further evaluation and/or exploration work required to verify and disclose the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with the Mining Reporting Standard; and (c) status of the proposed source of funding for the evaluation and/or exploration work referred to in Rule 11.7.6(1)(b); and (2) if it has been more than three years since the first disclosure of the Non-Equivalent Estimates under Rule 11.7.4 and those estimates have not been subsequently verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, then the Mining Reporting Entity must disclose in its Summary of Reserves and Resources: (a) an explanation of why the Non-Equivalent Estimates have not been verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and (b) the Mining Reporting Entity’s intention, proposed timetable and proposed source of funding with regard to verifying and disclosing the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard.

question: How does an Authorised Person figure out its Leverage Ratio using the Exposure Measure and Capital Measure?
answer: To figure out its Leverage Ratio, an Authorised Person needs to divide its Tier 1 Capital, known as the Capital Measure, by the Exposure Measure. The Exposure Measure is calculated by adding up all on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet items. This method ensures that the Leverage Ratio gives a true picture of the Authorised Person's financial standing, as required [#TGT:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c] and permitted [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person must calculate its Leverage Ratio in accordance with the following methodology: Leverage Ratio = Capital Measure Exposure Measure where: (a) "Capital Measure" represents the Tier 1 Capital of the Authorised Person calculated in accordance with Rule 3.9.1; and (b) "Exposure Measure" represents the value of Exposures of the Authorised Person calculated in accordance with Rules 3.21.5 and 3.21.6.
target_passage_text: The Exposure Measure under Rule 3.21.2(b) must be calculated as the sum of: (a) on-balance sheet items; and (b) off-balance sheet items.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate its Total Risk Exposure Amount, considering the need to multiply certain capital requirements by a specific factor?
answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Total Risk Exposure Amount by summing various Risk Exposure Amounts, including those for Credit, Market, Operational, CVA, and Displaced Commercial Risks, as applicable. In doing so, the Authorised Person must take into account the provisions of Rule 3.5.8. Specifically, for the Risk Exposure Amounts associated with Market, Operational, CVA, and Displaced Commercial Risks, the Authorised Person must multiply the individual capital requirements by a factor of 12.5. This multiplication is necessary to determine the Risk Exposure Amounts for these elements of the Total Risk Exposure Amount. The calculated Total Risk Exposure Amount reflects the comprehensive risk profile of the Authorised Person, ensuring that all relevant risk factors are appropriately accounted for in compliance with regulatory requirements [#SRC:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e] and [#TGT:c6eab1e6-6274-4d4d-b4b7-22ad0f9fe1c1].
source_passage_text: Total Risk Exposure Amount. An Authorised Person must calculate its Total Risk Exposure Amount, after taking into account the provisions of Rule 3.5.8, as the sum of: (a) the Credit RWA as calculated using Rule 4.8.1(2); (b) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the Market Risk Capital Requirement; (c) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the Operational Risk Capital Requirement; (d) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the CVA Risk Capital Requirement; and (e) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, where applicable, calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5.
target_passage_text: Total Risk Exposure Amount. An Authorised Person must multiply the individual capital requirements referred to under points 3.5.7(b) to 3.5.7(e) by a factor of 12.5 in order to determine the Risk Exposure Amounts associated with those elements of the Total Risk Exposure Amount.

question: If an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession, or a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing late, what fee must they pay?
answer: When an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession, or a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing after the deadline, they must pay a fee of $500 to the Regulator. This fee is required to ensure that all parties comply with the submission deadlines. In addition to this fee, the Regulator may also take further actions if necessary. The fee acts as a penalty for late submissions and encourages timely compliance with regulatory requirements. This ensures that all filings are submitted within the designated timeframes, maintaining the integrity and efficiency of the regulatory process. The imposition of such fees highlights the importance of adhering to deadlines and the consequences of failing to do so [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] and [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187].
source_passage_text: FEES 1.2.7 sets out the fees payable for late submission of Regulatory Filings. In addition to the imposition of a fee, the Regulator may take further action.
target_passage_text: Late Payment Fees relating to Regulatory Filings An Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body that submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date must pay to the Regulator a fee of $500.

question: Under what conditions may a Customer, who is not a Natural Person, agree with a Third Party Provider that the rules regarding withdrawal of consent do not apply, and how does this relate to the Customer's ability to withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction?
answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person may agree in writing with a Third Party Provider that specific rules, including those concerning the withdrawal of consent, do not apply. This agreement allows them to bypass the standard regulations that would otherwise govern such transactions. However, under the general permissions, the Customer retains the right to withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the transaction reaches a point where it can no longer be revoked, as specified in the relevant rules. This means that even if certain rules are agreed to be non-applicable, the Customer's ability to withdraw consent remains intact until the transaction becomes irrevocable. This dual framework ensures that while some regulatory requirements can be waived through mutual agreement, the fundamental right to withdraw consent is preserved until a specific point in the transaction process [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] and [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c].
source_passage_text: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 20.2.15 and 20.2.16 (charges for information); (b) Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 20.8.2 (revocation of a Payment Order); (d) Rules 20.10.1 and 20.10.2 (requests for refund); (e) Rule 20.11.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (f) Rule 20.12.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1.
target_passage_text: The Customer may withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the point at which the Third Party Transaction can no longer be revoked as set out in Rule 20.8.2.

question: Under what circumstances is an Authorised Person prohibited from entering into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement with a Retail Client?
answer: An Authorised Person must not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement in respect of an asset belonging to a Retail Client. This prohibition ensures that the assets of Retail Clients are protected from being transferred under such agreements, which could otherwise expose them to unnecessary risks. The regulatory framework is designed to safeguard the interests of Retail Clients by restricting the ability of Authorised Persons to engage in these agreements with them. This measure is crucial to maintain the integrity of client asset protection and to prevent potential conflicts of interest or misuse of client assets. By adhering to this prohibition, Authorised Persons contribute to the overall stability and trust in the financial system, ensuring that Retail Clients' assets are not improperly utilized or transferred without their explicit consent and understanding. This regulatory stance is consistent with broader efforts to enhance consumer protection in financial markets [#SRC:f8d4b63b-c965-42c6-abf2-f70dfb84afaa] and [#TGT:45762c70-0a0b-47e4-9db7-e70b9924abeb].
source_passage_text: Pursuant to Rule 15.11.A.1, an Authorised Person may not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement with a Retail Client.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement in respect of an asset belonging to a Retail Client.

question: When must a Mining Reporting Entity include specific assumptions in its disclosures, and how do these requirements relate to the classification and disclosure of Ore Reserves?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is required to include all material economic assumptions in its disclosures when reporting pursuant to specific rules. This includes providing a statement and explanation if any assumptions are deemed commercially sensitive. These disclosures are essential for determining forecast financial information and must also encompass all other material assumptions and the Production Target. The classification and disclosure of Ore Reserves are governed by additional requirements set out in various codes, such as the JORC Code, SAMREC Code, and NI 43-101. These codes provide further guidance on how Ore Reserves should be classified and disclosed, ensuring that the information is comprehensive and meets industry standards. The interplay between these disclosure obligations and the classification requirements ensures that stakeholders receive a complete and transparent view of the Mining Reporting Entity's financial forecasts and resource evaluations, as required [#TGT:4c6cbca4-a6c7-4b55-bebf-aeac86955d19] and permitted [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When an Issuer seeks to make an Offer of Digital Securities, may the Regulator deem an investment not typically classified as a Security to be a Security, and what role do legal advisers play in this process?
answer: In the context of an Issuer making an Offer of Digital Securities, the Regulator has the authority to deem an investment that is not typically classified as a Security to be a Security for regulatory purposes. This action can be taken through a written notice and is subject to terms and conditions deemed appropriate by the Regulator. The appointment of suitable legal advisers is crucial in this process, as they provide the necessary expertise to ensure compliance with applicable regulations, including the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR) and the Markets Rules (MKT). These legal advisers are expected to engage directly with the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA) throughout the Offer process, particularly in drafting and reviewing Offer documentation. Their involvement helps ensure that the Issuer meets all regulatory requirements, including those related to the classification of Digital Securities. This collaboration between the Issuer, its legal advisers, and the Regulator facilitates a compliant and efficient Offer process [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].
source_passage_text: MARKETS RULES OFFERS OF SECURITIES TO THE PUBLIC Appointment of Legal Advisers Issuers seeking to make an Offer of Digital Securities should consider the appointment of suitable legal advisers, with the appropriate skills, knowledge and experience to provide the requisite assistance to the Issuer throughout the Offer process. The FSRA expects that such legal advisers would assist in ensuring an Issuers compliance with the applicable provisions of FSMR (including having the FSRA deem a Digital Security a Security under FSMR Section 58(2)(b)), and MKT (including in relation to the Listing Rules within MKT). The FSRA would generally expect to have direct engagement with an Issuers legal advisers throughout this process, particularly in relation to the drafting, and FSRA review, of Offer documentation.
target_passage_text: Without limiting the generality of its powers, the Regulator may, by written notice— (a) exclude the application of any requirements; or (b) deem any investment which is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of these Regulations and the Rules made under these Regulations; subject to such terms and conditions as it may consider appropriate.

question: Under what conditions must a Captive Insurer mark-to-market its investments, and which types of investments are included within the scope of this requirement?
answer: A Captive Insurer is required to mark-to-market its investments to measure their value, wherever possible. This obligation applies specifically to investments and positions as outlined in the relevant rules. The scope of this requirement includes various types of investments such as debt securities, bonds, money-market and capital-market instruments, loans, shares, units in Collective Investment Funds, Derivatives, and any balance sheet positions measured at market or fair value. However, it is important to note that this requirement is subject to exceptions set out in the applicable chapter, which may influence the specific application of the rule [#SRC:d3ab7118-2ac1-4bd3-a89d-3f2776cb744f] and [#TGT:7b75295d-3023-4980-9ca8-71a527649045].
source_passage_text: Wherever possible, a Captive Insurer must mark-to-market in order to measure the value of the investments and positions to which this Rule applies under Rule 6.6.1. Marking to market is valuation at readily available close out prices from independent sources.
target_passage_text: Subject to the exceptions set out in this Chapter, Rule ‎6.6.2 applies in relation to the valuation of Investments that are, or amounts arising from the disposal of: (a) debt securities, bonds and other money-market and capital-market instruments; (b) loans; (c) shares and other variable yield participations; (d) units in Collective Investment Funds; (e) Derivatives; and (f) any balance sheet position measured at market value or fair value.

question: How is an Offer of Securities to the Public defined, and what exclusions apply to communications related to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange or regulatory reporting?
answer: An Offer of Securities to the Public is defined as a communication to any person, in any form or by any means, that presents information about the offer and the securities in a manner that enables an investor to decide whether to buy or subscribe to those securities. This definition is crucial for understanding the scope of what constitutes a public offer. However, certain communications are excluded from this definition. Specifically, communications related to the trading of securities already admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange are not considered offers to the public. Additionally, communications made for the purpose of complying with ongoing reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange are also excluded. These exclusions are important as they delineate the boundaries of regulatory oversight and ensure that routine trading and compliance communications are not unnecessarily restricted. Understanding these definitions and exclusions is essential for issuers and other market participants to navigate the regulatory landscape effectively [#SRC:b3c9bf5b-e0ac-4be7-badf-15646cde6e09] and [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310].
source_passage_text: MARKETS RULES OFFERS OF SECURITIES TO THE PUBLIC Offers of Securities As set out in section 59 of FSMR, an Offer of Securities to the Public is a communication to any person in any form or by any means presenting information on the Offer and the Securities offered so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities.
target_passage_text: General prohibitions and definitions. Definition of an Offer of Securities An Offer of Securities means a communication to any person in any form or by any means, presenting information on the terms of the Offer and the Securities offered, so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities but excluding— (a) any communication in connection with the trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange; (b) any communication made for the purposes of complying with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange; or (c) any other communication prescribed in Rules as an exempt communication.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, under what conditions may they recognise the effect of such Collateral, and what must they do if the SFT is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement?
answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT may recognise the effect of such Collateral when the pre-settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined according to specific rules. However, if the SFT is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA, they must calculate E* in accordance with designated rules and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure. This ensures compliance with the regulatory framework, allowing the Authorised Person to accurately assess and manage the associated risks [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] and [#TGT:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de].
source_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.

question: When must Client Money, paid out by cheque or other payable order, remain in a Client Account until it is cleared by the recipient's bank, and what conditions allow for its earlier release?
answer: Client Money that is paid out by cheque or other payable order must remain in a Client Account until the cheque or payable order is presented to and cleared by the recipient's bank. This requirement ensures that the funds are not prematurely withdrawn, maintaining the integrity of the Client Account. However, there are specific conditions under which Client Money may be released earlier. These include situations where the money is due and payable to the Authorised Person, paid to the Client on whose behalf it is held, or paid in accordance with a Client instruction. Additionally, the money can be released if it is required to meet the payment obligations of the Client, becomes held by the Authorised Person under a title transfer collateral arrangement, or is held by the Authorised Person as a bank deposit. Other authorised circumstances by the Regulator may also permit earlier release of the funds. These provisions ensure that Client Money is managed responsibly while allowing for necessary flexibility in its handling [#SRC:385a7557-f9e5-4b07-a74c-708290be41b7] and [#TGT:82f4dd91-6456-4056-9627-c19a17842694].
source_passage_text: Subject to Rule 14.8.2, Client Money must remain in a Client Account until it: (a) is due and payable to the Authorised Person; (b) is paid to the Client on whose behalf the Client Money is held; (c) is paid in accordance with a Client instruction on whose behalf the Client Money is held; (d) is required to meet the payment obligations of the Client on whose behalf the Client Money is held; (e) becomes held by the Authorised Person pursuant to a title transfer collateral arrangement; (f) becomes held by the Authorised Person in its capacity as a bank as a Deposit; or (g) is paid out in circumstances that are otherwise authorised by the Regulator.
target_passage_text: Client Money paid out by way of cheque or other payable order under Rule ‎14.8.1A(b) or (c) must remain in a Client Account until the cheque or payable order is presented to and cleared by the recipient’s bank.

question: Under what conditions may a Foreign Fund be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, considering the requirements for listing on an Official List?
answer: A Foreign Fund can be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange if it meets specific criteria. The Fund must be from a Recognised Jurisdiction or be approved by the Regulator as subject to equivalent regulation. Additionally, for a Person to have the Units of such a Fund admitted to an Official List, the Fund must be regulated from a Recognised Jurisdiction or approved by the Regulator as subject to equivalent regulation to a Public Fund. If the Fund is intended to be a Property Fund, it must be closed-ended with at least 60% of its assets comprising Real Property. These conditions ensure that Foreign Funds adhere to financial and periodic reporting requirements similar to those for Domestic Funds, thereby maintaining regulatory consistency across jurisdictions [#SRC:4dfab9ab-e004-4159-9273-0bf8e49e9b87] and [#TGT:62faaa96-65f3-443e-b76c-0c846bc2b135].
source_passage_text: Under Rule 3.2.1, a Foreign Fund can be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange if it is from a Recognised Jurisdictions or approved by the Regulator as a Fund subject to equivalent regulation. Accordingly, such Funds would be subject to financial and periodic reporting requirements that are similar to the financial reporting requirements applicable to Domestic Funds.
target_passage_text: A Person may have the Units of a Fund admitted to an Official List only if: (1) in the case of a Domestic Fund, it is a Public Fund; and (2) in the case of a Foreign Fund: (a) it is a regulated Fund from a Recognised Jurisdiction; or (b) it is a Fund approved by the Regulator as a Fund subject to equivalent regulation as that applying to a Public Fund; and (3) it is intended to be a Property Fund, it is closed ended and 60% or more of the Fund's assets comprise Real Property.

question: How shall an Authorised Person calculate E* for pre-settlement counterparty exposures arising from SFTs when eligible financial collateral is taken, and what methods must be used for determining the appropriate haircuts?
answer: An Authorised Person must calculate E* for pre-settlement counterparty exposures arising from SFTs by adhering to specific rules outlined in the applicable regulatory framework. This calculation is necessary when eligible financial collateral is taken, and the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral netting agreement. The Authorised Person is required to follow the procedures specified in the rules to substitute E* for E when determining the credit risk-weighted exposure amount. To accurately determine E*, the Authorised Person must calculate the appropriate haircuts to be applied. This can be achieved by using one of two methods: either the standard supervisory haircuts or the own estimate haircuts. The choice between these methods allows the Authorised Person to align the haircut calculation with regulatory expectations while ensuring that the credit risk exposure is accurately assessed and managed. This dual approach ensures compliance with regulatory obligations and facilitates effective risk management as required [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] and permitted [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de].
source_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.
target_passage_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person must calculate the appropriate haircuts to be applied using one of the following methods: (a) standard supervisory haircuts; or (b) own estimate haircuts.

question: When can a company not issue more Equity Securities without approval, and how does later approval change this?
answer: A company must not issue more Equity Securities than allowed by a specific formula unless it gets approval from its shareholders first. This formula considers the number of shares from the past year and other factors. If a company issues shares without this approval but stays within the limit, it can still be okay if shareholders approve it within three months after the issue. This later approval makes the issue valid, even though it didn't have approval at first. So, while the company can't issue too many shares without approval, getting approval afterward can fix this, as long as certain conditions are met [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] and [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
source_passage_text: Subsequent approval of an issue of Securities. An issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 is treated as having been made with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1 if: (1) the issue or agreement did not exceed the limit in Rule 9.7.1; (2) the holders of the Listed Entitys Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it; and (3) the Securities are issued within three months of the date of the approval.
target_passage_text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. (4) partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement, but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement. Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than: (a) with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or (b) under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: What procedural steps must the Listing Authority follow when issuing an aware letter to a Reporting Entity, and how does this relate to the subsequent disclosure process?
answer: When the Listing Authority determines that a Reporting Entity has not disclosed information in a timely manner, it may issue an aware letter. This occurs after an enquiry confirms that the information is accurate, constitutes Inside Information, and is not exempt from disclosure. Once the Reporting Entity's response to the enquiry is received and reviewed, both the aware letter and the response are typically disclosed together. This disclosure ensures that the market is informed about the Listing Authority's enquiries and the Reporting Entity's response, thereby maintaining transparency in the market for the Listed Entity's Securities. The process underscores the Listing Authority's role in supervising compliance and ensuring that disclosures are made promptly, thereby upholding market integrity [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] and [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4].
source_passage_text: SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an aware letter (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_passage_text: SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY Aware Letters When a Reporting Entity’s response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response will usually be Disclosed together by the Listing Authority, so that the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries of the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures, and of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries.

question: When can the FSRA decide to lower or not charge fees for someone doing both regular and Spot Commodity activities?
answer: The FSRA can decide to lower or not charge fees for someone doing both regular and Spot Commodity activities if it thinks it's fair and reasonable for that specific situation. This is important because people doing Spot Commodity activities might already be paying high fees. The FSRA can choose to reduce, waive, or give back all or part of any fee, including extra or late fees, if it believes it's the right thing to do. This helps make sure that the fees are fair and don't put too much pressure on people doing more than one type of regulated activity. The FSRA looks at each case to decide if it's fair and reasonable to change the fees based on what's happening in that particular case [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] and [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036].
source_passage_text: FEES Cumulative application of Fees Noting the above paragraph, if an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets (e.g., Securities or Derivatives) in addition to Spot Commodities, it will need to seek approval from the FSRA for its FSP to permit it to carry out its Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types (conventional and Spot Commodities). The fees attributable to that Authorised Person for its Regulated Activities, conventional and Spot Commodity-related, may not be cumulative should the FSRA apply its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, under FEES 1.2.8 (considering the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities.
target_passage_text: Relief from Payment The Regulator may at any time reduce, waive or refund all or part of any fee including any supplementary or late payment fee if it considers that, in the circumstances of a particular case, it would be fair and reasonable to do so.

question: When can't the Regulator and Investigator share what someone says in an interview with the police for a criminal case?
answer: The Regulator and Investigator must not share what a person says in an interview with the police for a criminal case unless certain conditions are met. These conditions are that the person must agree to the sharing, or the Regulator must be legally required to share the information by law or a court order. This rule is in place to protect the person's privacy and ensure that their statements are not used against them unfairly in criminal proceedings. Both the Regulator and the Investigator have to follow these rules to maintain confidentiality and comply with legal standards [#SRC:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6] and [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff].
source_passage_text: In addition to the overriding duty of confidentiality set out in section 198, section 207(2) of the FSMR prohibits the Regulator from disclosing a statement made by a person to an investigator at an interview conducted pursuant to section 206(1)(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against that person unless: (a) the person consents to the disclosure; or (b) the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_passage_text: The Investigator shall not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to any question asked pursuant to a requirement made of the person under section ‎206‎(1)‎(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person unless— (a) the person consents to the disclosure; or (b) the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.

question: What do Domestic Firms need to do to make sure they can pay their debts on time, considering both liquidity and capital resources?
answer: Domestic Firms, which are Authorised Persons, need to keep enough capital resources at all times, as specified by the rules, to ensure they can pay their debts when they are due. This involves having the right types and amounts of capital resources. Additionally, they must have extra capital and liquid assets that match the nature, size, and complexity of their business. This helps make sure there is no significant risk of not being able to meet liabilities. To manage liquidity, firms can hold enough cash or assets that can be quickly sold, plan their cashflows to match future needs, or borrow more if necessary. These steps help ensure that the firm can meet its financial obligations on time, fulfilling both liquidity and capital resource requirements [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87] and [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56].
source_passage_text: In accordance with Rule 3.2.2 or Rule 3.2.4, an Authorised Person is required to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. With specific reference to liquidity, an Authorised Person may meet its obligations in a number of ways, including: a. by holding sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets; b. by securing an appropriate matching future profile of cashflows; and c. by further borrowing.
target_passage_text: Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must: (a) have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules; (b) ensure that it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the requirement in (a) which are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due.

question: What insurance coverage requirements must a Third Party Provider meet to ensure compliance with both maintaining sufficient professional indemnity insurance and transaction limits?
answer: A Third Party Provider is obligated to maintain professional indemnity insurance that is sufficient to cover potential reimbursements to customers in the event of operational risk events. This requirement ensures that the provider can address any liabilities arising from such risks. Additionally, the provider must ensure that the remaining coverage of this insurance is always greater than thirty times the average daily value of all Third Party Transactions conducted over the past ninety calendar days. This dual requirement ensures that the provider not only has adequate coverage to address specific operational risks but also maintains a level of insurance that reflects the scale of its transaction activities. By adhering to these obligations, the provider can effectively manage its risk exposure and maintain financial stability, thereby safeguarding the interests of its customers and ensuring regulatory compliance [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] and [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b].
source_passage_text: Rule 6.12A.2 requires a Third Party Provider to maintain sufficient professional indemnity insurance coverage to reimburse Customers should operational risk events occur.
target_passage_text: Transaction Limits. A Third Party Provider must ensure that its remaining professional indemnity insurance coverage is always greater than thirty times the average daily value of all Third Party Transactions in the past ninety calendar days.

question: What must a Petroleum Reporting Entity ensure is included in the disclosure when presenting new estimates of material Contingent Resources that have not been previously disclosed?
answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must ensure that the disclosure of new, material estimates of Contingent Resources, which have not been previously disclosed, includes several critical elements. These elements encompass the types of permits or licences held by the entity that are relevant to the disclosed estimates. Additionally, the disclosure must provide the basis for confirming the existence of a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum and the determination of a discovery. Furthermore, a detailed description of the estimation method, key contingencies, and any further appraisal drilling and evaluation work planned to assess commercial recovery potential must be included. If the estimates are contingent on technology under development, the disclosure must explain the commercial viability of the technology in analogous or other reservoirs, or its active development status with evidence of potential availability within five years. Lastly, if the estimates relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, the disclosure must detail the type of resource, land area, number of wells, and proposed specialised extraction technology [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] as required [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704].
source_passage_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity making a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relating to the estimates; (2) an explanation of the new data and information; (3) an explanation of how the new data and information has affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources; and (4) any changes or additions to the information previously disclosed relating to: (a) Prospective Resources under Rules 12.8.1(1) to 12.8.1(4); (b) Contingent Resources under Rules 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5); and (c) Petroleum Reserves under Rules 12.12.1(1) to 12.12.1(7).
target_passage_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity disclosing estimates of Contingent Resources that are material, and that have not previously been disclosed by the Petroleum Reporting Entity, must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relevant to the disclosed estimates of Contingent Resources; (2) the basis for, confirming the existence of a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum, and the determination of a discovery; (3) a description of: (a) the method of estimation; (b) the key contingencies that resulted in the estimates being classified as Contingent Resources; (c) any further appraisal drilling and evaluation work to be undertaken to assess the potential for commercial recovery, and to progress the relevant project; (4) if the disclosed estimates of Contingent Resources are contingent on technology under development, to ensure that Unrecoverable quantities are not classified as part of the Contingent Resources, an explanation of whether the technology has: (a) been demonstrated to be commercially viable in analogous reservoirs; (b) been demonstrated to be commercially viable in other reservoirs that are not analogous, and that a pilot project, which is planned and budgeted, will be necessary to demonstrate commerciality for this reservoir; or (c) not been demonstrated to be commercially viable, but is currently under active development, and there is sufficient evidence to indicate that the technology may reasonably be expected to be available for commercial application within five years; and (5) if the disclosed estimates of Contingent Resources relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, the: (a) type(s) of Unconventional Contingent Resource; (b) land area; (c) number of wells; and (d) specialised extraction technology proposed to be utilised.

question: When can the Regulator let a Recognised Investment Exchange delay making trade details public, and what must the Exchange do if this happens?
answer: The Regulator can allow a Recognised Investment Exchange to delay making trade details public for large trades or specific types of trades. If this delay is permitted, the Exchange must inform its Members, users, and investors about the delay and its terms. Even with a delay, the Exchange still needs to make sure that trade details like price, volume, and time are shared with the public and the Regulator as quickly as possible. This includes making sure that details of portfolio trades are shared in a timely way and that information about trades happening outside normal hours is made public before the next trading day starts. These steps help keep the market transparent and fair, even when some details are delayed [#SRC:7f823646-b062-4581-a37a-a39040c4edad] and [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6].
source_passage_text: Deferrals. The Regulator may permit the requirements of Rule 3.6.1 to be deferred in respect of large volume or for certain types of trades, as specified in Rule 3.6.8, in which case the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure that the existence of and the terms of the deferral are disclosed to Members and users of their facilities, and to investors.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange must make arrangements for the price, volume and time of transactions executed in Financial Instruments to be made available to the public and the Regulator as close to real-time as technically possible assuming a reasonable level of efficiency and of expenditure on systems on the part of the Recognised Investment Exchange, provided that: (a) information relating to a portfolio trade shall be made available with respect to each constituent transaction as close to real time as possible, having regard to the need to allocate prices to particular Financial Instruments; and (b) post-trade information referring to transactions taking place on a Recognised Investment Exchange but outside its normal trading hours shall be made public before the opening of the next trading day of the Recognised Investment Exchange.

question: What are the obligations for an Applicant seeking admission of Digital Securities to the Official List concerning the listing fee, and how does this relate to the application fee required for a Financial Services Permission to provide Money Services?
answer: An Applicant seeking admission of Digital Securities to the Official List must pay a listing fee of US$3,000 as required for such admissions. This fee is distinct from the application fee obligations for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services. Specifically, an Applicant must pay an application fee to the Regulator, which varies based on the specific activity. For instance, the fee for Currency Exchange or Money Remittance is $15,000, while Payment Services require a $25,000 fee. These fees are structured to align with the nature of the financial services activity being undertaken. Therefore, while both fees are mandatory, they apply to different contexts and activities, with the listing fee pertaining to the admission of Digital Securities and the application fee relating to the provision of money services [#SRC:e6bea365-9269-4a14-ac6b-2ccf805f85f9] [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b].
source_passage_text: FEES Fees Prospectus Offers and Admission to Official List The listing fee for an admission of Digital Securities to the Official List of Securities is US$3,000 as set out in FEES Rule 3.9.1.
target_passage_text: An Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services must pay to the Regulator an application fee as detailed in the table below, in accordance with the activity that it will carry on. /Table Start Activity Application fee ($) Currency exchange or Money Remittance 15,000 Payment Services 25,000 /Table End

question: If an Authorised Person can't meet its LCR Requirement, what must it do, and when can it sell HQLA to get cash during stress?
answer: If an Authorised Person finds it cannot meet its LCR Requirement, it must immediately notify the Regulator in writing. This is important to keep the Regulator informed about any liquidity problems. At the same time, if the Authorised Person is experiencing financial or liquidity stress, it is allowed to sell some of its High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA) to get cash and cover cash outflows. This selling might make the HQLA levels drop below what's usually required, but this is acceptable only as much as needed to handle the cash outflows during the stress period. This ensures that the Authorised Person can manage its liquidity needs while keeping the Regulator updated about its compliance status [#SRC:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c] and [#TGT:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f].
source_passage_text: Notification if LCR Requirement is not met . An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing immediately if it does not meet, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting, at any time, its LCR Requirement (including during a period of stress referred to in Rule 9.3.8).
target_passage_text: Liquidation of assets during periods of stress . During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person may liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows. Subject to Rule 9.3.9, the Authorised Person's level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with cash outflows during that period.

question: What must a Listed Entity do to ensure an issue is approved, and what are the limits on issuing new Equity Securities?
answer: A Listed Entity must ensure that any issue is approved under the relevant rule to comply with regulations. The entity is not allowed to issue more Equity Securities than a specific limit unless they have approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities. This limit is calculated using a formula that takes into account the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the past 12 months, excluding those issued under certain exceptions or without necessary approvals. By adhering to these guidelines, the entity ensures that any new issuance is properly authorized and within the allowed limits, thus maintaining regulatory compliance [#SRC:b0911de0-2418-4fb5-9565-683577084295] and [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
source_passage_text: In the case of (a) above, the issue must have been approved under Rule 9.7.1.
target_passage_text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. (4) partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement, but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement. Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than: (a) with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or (b) under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: When does the Regulator think conduct might create an artificial price, and when are transactions not allowed?
answer: The Regulator looks at several things to decide if conduct might create an artificial price. They check how much someone is interested in the price or value of a Financial Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset, or Accepted Spot Commodity. They also see if the price changes are unusual compared to normal patterns. Additionally, they consider if someone keeps changing their bids or offers. Transactions are not allowed if they aren't for real reasons and don't follow Accepted Market Practices. These transactions must not give a wrong idea about the supply, demand, or price of the instruments, and they shouldn't make the price abnormal or fake. This helps keep the market fair and stops actions that could mislead others about the true market situation [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] and [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f].
source_passage_text: Factors relating to creating an artificial price. In considering whether or not conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price under section 92(4)(b), the Regulator is likely to take into account factors such as: (a) the extent to which the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity; (b) the extent to which price, rate or option volatility movements, and the volatility of these factors for the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity in question, are outside their normal intra-day, daily, weekly or monthly range; or (c) whether a person has successively and consistently increased or decreased his bid, Offer or the price he has paid for a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity.
target_passage_text: The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which— (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or (b) secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action, and how does this relate to the exercise of Resolution Tools or Powers?
answer: The Regulator may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part if certain conditions are met, such as adverse effects on financial stability in the ADGM or material fiscal implications for the UAE or ADGM. This refusal is contingent upon the satisfaction of specific criteria, including the necessity of taking Resolution Action to achieve Resolution Objectives or ensuring equitable treatment of creditors in the ADGM compared to those in non-ADGM jurisdictions. In relation to this, the Regulator is permitted to exercise one or more Resolution Tools or Powers to support or give full effect to a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action. However, this exercise is subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval, ensuring compliance with legal standards. The interplay between these permissions allows the Regulator to balance the need for effective resolution actions with the protection of financial stability and legal rights within the ADGM [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] and [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29].
source_passage_text: The Regulator may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part if it is satisfied that one or more of the following conditions are met (a) recognition would have an adverse effect on financial stability in the ADGM; (b) the Resolution Conditions have not been met in relation to the entity listed in section 2 with respect to which the Regulator proposes to take Resolution Action pursuant to section 78(5); (c) the taking of Resolution Action by the Regulator in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5) is not necessary to achieve one or more of the Resolution Objectives; (d) under the Foreign Resolution Action, creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not, by reason of being located in the ADGM, receive the same treatment, and have similar legal rights, as creditors (including depositors) who are located or payable in the non-ADGM jurisdiction concerned; or (e) recognition of, and taking action in support of, the Foreign Resolution Action (or the relevant part) would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools, or one or more Resolution Powers, subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval in compliance with section 27.

question: What are the financial obligations for a Person applying for and subsequently granted a designation by the Regulator, specifically regarding the payment of fees?
answer: A Person applying to the Regulator for designations such as ADGM Green Fund or ADGM Climate Transition Fund must initially pay an application fee of $2,000. Once granted a designation under the relevant rule, the Person must also pay an annual designation fee of $2,000. This fee is prorated for the remainder of the calendar year following the initial granting of the designation. For subsequent years, the full fee is due by January 31 of the calendar year it pertains to. These financial obligations ensure that both the application and ongoing designation statuses are maintained as required [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] and permitted [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc].
source_passage_text: A Person granted a designation under Rule 10.1.1 must pay to the Regulator an annual designation fee of $2,000: (a) prorated for the remainder of the calendar year following the initial granting of the designation; and (b) for subsequent calendar years commencing 1 January, payable in full to the Regulator on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates.
target_passage_text: A Person applying to the Regulator for any of the following designations: (a) ADGM Green Fund; (b) ADGM Climate Transition Fund; (c) ADGM Green Portfolio; (d) ADGM Climate Transition Portfolio; (e) ADGM Green Bond; or (f) ADGM Sustainability Linked Bond must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $2,000.

question: When an Issuer is issuing a Prospectus in ADGM, what should a Mining Reporting Entity think about to make sure investors get all the information they need?
answer: When an Issuer is issuing a Prospectus in ADGM, a Mining Reporting Entity should think about whether to share sensitive details like pricing or contract volumes. This is important because the Prospectus must have all the information investors need to understand the Issuer's financial health, such as its assets, liabilities, profits, and losses. It should also explain the nature of the Securities and any rights or responsibilities that come with them. This helps investors make smart decisions about their investments. The FSRA expects this level of detail to be included, as it aligns with the rules that say investors should get all the information they would reasonably expect to find in a Prospectus [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] and [#TGT:84661a10-aff1-4513-8b63-a9bc2f25e5d9].
source_passage_text: ORE RESERVES . The FSRA does expect a Mining Reporting Entity to have to disclose commercially sensitive information (e.g., pricing or volumes under long term contractual commitments) to meet this Rule obligation. A Mining Reporting Entity (and other relevant entities) may, however, have to carefully consider whether this information needs to be disclosed to meet other disclosure requirements, including in reference to: a) where an Issuer is issuing a Prospectus within ADGM, and the requirement in section 62(1) of FSMR to include all information that investors would reasonably require and expect to find in a Prospectus for the purposes of making an informed investment decision; or b) the requirements in sections 95(2) of FSMR and Rule 7.2.1 to disclose information that would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price... of Financial Instruments.
target_passage_text: A Prospectus shall contain all the information which an investor would reasonably require and expect to find in a Prospectus for the purpose of making an informed assessment of— (a) the assets and liabilities, financial position, profits and losses and prospects of the Issuer and any guarantor; and (b) the nature of the Securities and the rights and liabilities attaching to those Securities.

question: When does a person have to pay for losses from a Prospectus, and when are they not liable for statements by public officials?
answer: A person must pay for losses from a Prospectus if they are prescribed by the Regulator and the loss is due to false or misleading statements or missing important information that should have been included. However, they are not liable for losses from statements made by public officials or in official documents if those statements are accurately and fairly reproduced in the Prospectus. This means that while they have to compensate for certain errors or omissions, they are not responsible for faithfully included official statements [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f] and [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac].
source_passage_text: A Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for any loss resulting from a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document which is included in the Prospectus if the statement is accurately and fairly reproduced.
target_passage_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: When someone does a reconciliation, what must they write down, and who needs to check it?
answer: When someone completes a reconciliation, they must write a statement confirming that it was done according to the specific requirements. After this, a senior member of the Authorised Person must review the reconciliation. This process ensures that the reconciliation is not only documented but also checked by someone with the right level of authority. This dual step of writing a statement and having a senior review helps maintain proper oversight and accountability in the reconciliation process, as required [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] and permitted [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30].

target_passage_text: A reconciliation performed in accordance with Rule ‎15.9.1 must be reviewed by a member of the Authorised Person who has adequate seniority.

question: When a Relevant Person assesses whether AML/TFS regulations in another jurisdiction align with FATF standards, what factors must they consider, and under what conditions may they rely on a third party for CDD information?
answer: A Relevant Person must consider various factors when assessing if AML/TFS regulations in another jurisdiction are equivalent to FATF standards. These factors include mutual evaluations, membership in international groups, and contextual elements like political stability. Additionally, evidence of criticism or cooperation arrangements with the jurisdiction's regulator must be taken into account. When relying on a third party for Customer Due Diligence (CDD) information, the Relevant Person may do so only if they immediately obtain necessary CDD information and ensure certified document copies are available on request. The third party must be regulated by a competent authority in a country with AML/TFS regulations equivalent to FATF standards and must not have relied on exceptions for CDD elements. The information must also be current [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] and [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275].
source_passage_text: When assessing under Rule 9.1.1(3) or (4) if AML/TFS regulations in another jurisdiction are equivalent to FATF standards, a Relevant Person must take into account factors including, but not limited to: (a) mutual evaluations, assessment reports or follow-up reports published by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD or other International Organisations; (b) membership of FATF or other international or regional groups such as the MENAFATF or the Gulf Co-operation Council; (c) contextual factors such as political stability or the level of corruption in the jurisdiction; (d) evidence of recent criticism of the jurisdiction, including in: (i) FATF advisory notices; (ii) public assessments of the jurisdictions AML/TFS regimes by organisations referred to in (a); or (iii) reports by other relevant non-government organisations or specialist commercial organisations; (e) whether adequate arrangements exist for co-operation between the AML/TFS regulator in that jurisdiction and the Regulator.
target_passage_text: Where a Relevant Person seeks to rely on a Person in (1) it may only do so if and to the extent that: (a) it immediately obtains the necessary CDD information from the third party in (1); (b) it takes adequate steps to satisfy itself that certified copies of the documents used to undertake the relevant elements of CDD will be available from the third party on request without delay; (c) the Person in (1)(b) to (d) is subject to regulation, including AML/TFS compliance requirements, by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a country with AML/TFS regulations which are equivalent to the standards set out in the FATF Recommendations and it is supervised for compliance with such regulations; (d) the Person in (1) has not relied on any exception from the requirement to conduct any relevant elements of CDD which the Relevant Person seeks to rely on; and (e) in relation to (2), the information is up to date.

question: What must a Recognised Investment Exchange do to categorise people for weekly reports on trading positions?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must categorise people according to specific rules when creating weekly reports on trading positions. This means they need to separate positions that reduce risks related to business activities from other positions. The Exchange also has to make these reports public and send them to the Regulator. The reports should show the total positions for each participant category for every derivative traded, including the number of long and short positions, changes since the last report, the percentage of total open interest for each category, and how many people hold positions in each category. These steps help ensure transparency and meet regulatory requirements [#SRC:2722b40a-c3fd-4d87-a5aa-65796ac6bdf2] and [#TGT:ce2f97e5-2183-47cc-a1b0-23f2db75b226].
source_passage_text: Position Reports. For the weekly report referred to under Rule 3.3.12, the Recognised Investment Exchange must: (a) categorise persons in accordance with Rule 3.3.15; and (b) differentiate, to the extent possible, between positions identified as: (i) positions which in an objectively measurable way reduce risks directly relating to commercial activities; and (ii) other positions.
target_passage_text: Position Reports. A Recognised Investment Exchange must make public, and provide to the Regulator, a weekly report detailing the aggregate positions held by each category of participant for each Derivative that is admitted to trading on the Recognised Investment Exchange, specifying: (a) the number of long and short positions by such categories; (b) any changes in positions since the previous report; (c) the percentage of the total open interest represented by each category of participant; and (d) the number of persons holding a position in each category of participant.
