question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person defer the publication of transaction information, and what procedural steps must be followed to determine the appropriate delay based on the class of Financial Instrument?
answer: An Authorised Person may defer the publication of transaction information if the transaction is conducted between a Member or the Authorised Person dealing on their own account and a Client, and if the transaction size meets or exceeds the minimum qualifying size specified for the relevant class of Financial Instrument. The procedural steps to determine the appropriate delay involve classifying the Financial Instrument according to its average daily turnover (ADT). The table provided outlines the permitted delays and the corresponding minimum qualifying sizes for each class of Financial Instrument based on their ADT. For instance, a transaction involving a Financial Instrument with an ADT of less than or equal to 100,000 USD may qualify for a 60-minute delay if the transaction size is at least 10,000 USD. The delay period can extend up to the end of the third trading day after the trade, depending on the ADT and the transaction size. These steps ensure compliance with the specified criteria for deferred publication [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] and [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27].
source_passage_text: Deferred publication of large transactions The deferred publication of information in respect of transactions may be authorised, for a period no longer than the period specified in Rule 3.6.10 for the class of Financial Instrument and transaction concerned, provided the following criteria are satisfied: (a) the transaction is between a Member or if applicable, Authorised Person, dealing on own account and a Client of that firm; and (b) the size of that transaction is equal to or exceeds the relevant minimum qualifying size, as specified in Rule 3.6.10. In order to determine the relevant minimum qualifying size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange shall be classified in accordance with their average daily turnover to be calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6.10.
target_passage_text: Deferred publication thresholds and delays The table below shows, for each permitted delay for publication and each class of Financial Instrument in terms of average daily turnover (ADT), the minimum qualifying size of transaction that will qualify for that delay in respect of a Financial Instrument of that type. /Table Start Permitted delay for publication Class of Financial Instruments in terms of average daily turnover (ADT, in USD) ADT <= 100,000 100,000 < ADT <= 1,000,000 1,000,000 <= ADT < 50,000,000 ADT <> 50,000,000 Minimum qualifying size of transaction for permitted delay 60 minutes 10,000 max (5% of ADT, 25,000) min (10% of ADT, 3,500,000) min (10% of ADT, 7,500,000) 180 minutes 25,000 max (15% of ADT, 75,000) min (15% of ADT, 5,000,000) min (20% of ADT, 15,000,000) Until end of trading day (or roll-over to 12pm of next trading day if trade undertaken in final 12 hours of trading day) 45,000 max (25% of ADT, 100,000) min (25% of ADT, 10,000,000) min (30% of ADT, 30,000,000) Until end of trading day next after trade 60,000 max (50% of ADT, 100,000) max (50% of ADT, 1,000,000) 100% of ADT Until end of second trading day next after trade 80,000 100% of ADT 100% of ADT 250% of ADT Until end of third trading day next after trade 250% of ADT 250% of ADT /Table End

question: What steps must an Authorised Person take to ensure the Safe Custody Auditor's Report is properly submitted to the Regulator, and what specific statements must the Auditor include regarding Client Investments and compliance with Safe Custody Rules?
answer: An Authorised Person, whose Financial Service Permission allows holding Client Investments, is required to arrange for the submission of a Safe Custody Auditor's Report to the Regulator annually. In procuring this report, the Authorised Person must ensure that the Auditor includes specific statements about the extent of holding and controlling Client Investments, as well as compliance with Safe Custody Rules. The Auditor must confirm whether the Authorised Person has maintained adequate systems and controls throughout the year, whether Safe Custody Investments are properly registered and recorded, and if there have been any material discrepancies in reconciliations. Additionally, the Auditor must verify that all necessary information and explanations were received for preparing the report and note any unmet requirements of the Safe Custody Provisions. These steps ensure that the report comprehensively addresses the Authorised Person's compliance status and investment handling as required [#TGT:99e42871-85c3-4bd8-8cea-8366dc6a7607] and permitted [#SRC:005cd89b-9c47-4377-a477-1b159acd9ba8].
source_passage_text: In accordance with GEN 6.6.7, an Authorised Person whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Investments must arrange for a Safe Custody Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis.
target_passage_text: Safe Custody Auditor's Report: An Authorised Person must, in procuring the production of a Safe Custody Auditor's Report by its Auditor, ensure that the Auditor states, as at the date on which the Authorised Person's audited statement of financial position was prepared: (1) the extent to which the Authorised Person was holding and controlling Client Investments, Arranging Custody or Providing Custody; and (2) whether: (a) the Authorised Person has, throughout the year, maintained systems and controls to enable it to comply with the Safe Custody Rules in COBS Chapter 15; (b) the Safe Custody Investments are registered, recorded or held in accordance with the Safe Custody Rules; (c) there have been any material discrepancies in the reconciliation of Safe Custody Investments; (d) the Auditor has received all necessary information and explanations for the purposes of preparing this report to the Regulator; and (e) any of the requirements of the Safe Custody Provisions have not been met.

question: What should an Authorised Person tell a Retail Client about stop-loss orders in the risk disclosure statement before they start trading OTC Leveraged Products?
answer: Before a Retail Client begins trading OTC Leveraged Products, an Authorised Person must give them a risk disclosure statement. This statement needs to clearly warn the client about the risks, such as losing more than their initial investment and the chance of quick losses. It should also explain that tools like stop-loss orders might not always work as expected. Specifically, if stop-loss orders are relevant, the statement must explain whether these orders are guaranteed to work in all market conditions. If they are not guaranteed, the client should be informed that stop-loss orders might not prevent losses during very volatile market situations. This helps ensure that Retail Clients understand the risks involved in trading before they start, as required [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] and permitted [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8].
source_passage_text: Before an Authorised Person opens a trading account enabling a Retail Client to buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, it must: (a) provide a separate risk disclosure statement, as described in Rule 23.4.3, to Retail Clients as part of the onboarding process in good time before the Authorised Person carries on any business for a Retail Client; (b) obtain a documented acknowledgement from such Retail Client that they have received and reviewed the risk disclosure statement and fully understand and accept the risks involved in trading in OTC Leveraged Products; (c) provide a duplicate copy of the documented acknowledgement to each Retail Client; and (d) maintain a record of the acknowledgment in (b) in accordance with applicable record keeping requirements.
target_passage_text: A risk disclosure statement provided by an Authorised Person to a Retail Client in accordance with Rule 23.4.1 must include a prominent warning that investing in OTC Leveraged Products involves the risk of losing substantially more than the initial margin posted by the Retail Client, and further state that: (a) the risk disclosure statement may not identify or address all risks associated with OTC Leveraged Products; (b) the Retail Client is at risk of losing all of their capital outlay and any profits not redeemed; (c) the Retail Client is at risk of losing money and accumulating losses rapidly; (d) margin trading and use of leverage amplifies losses when they occur; (e) margin-trading limits, stop-loss limits, or other systems and controls designed to mitigate or limit loss exposures may not be effective or may fail. Where relevant, an explanation of stop-loss orders, which must include clear information about whether or not a stop-loss is “guaranteed” (i.e. it would operate whatever the market circumstances are), and that in the case that it is not guaranteed, it may not limit Retail Client losses in the event of highly volatile trading conditions in an underlying asset or reference price; (f) the risk of slippage, i.e. a divergence between the price at which a trade was approved and the price at which it was executed; and (g) most Retail Clients transacting in OTC Leveraged Products lose money.

question: When can the Regulator share Confidential Information with a criminal law enforcement agency, and what rules do they not have to follow?
answer: The Regulator can share Confidential Information with a criminal law enforcement agency for criminal investigations or proceedings. According to the TARGET passage, this is allowed if the disclosure is permitted or required by any law that applies to the Regulator, including international rules. The SOURCE passage adds that when the Regulator shares information with a criminal law enforcement agency, they do not have to follow the usual rules in subsection (2). This means that although the TARGET passage usually requires following subsection (2) for disclosures, the SOURCE passage provides an exception for criminal law enforcement agencies, so the Regulator can share information without those extra steps [#SRC:3ea3d5aa-2378-40cd-ab7a-f454859a385c] and [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1].
source_passage_text: Disclosure to a criminal law enforcement agency. Importantly, disclosure of Confidential Information by the Regulator to a criminal law enforcement agency, whether in the U.A.E or otherwise, for the purpose of any criminal investigation or criminal proceedings under paragraph 199(1)(b)(v) is not subject to the requirements under section 199(2).
target_passage_text: Subject to subsection (2), the Regulator may disclose Confidential Information for the purpose of facilitating the carrying out of a Public Function where such disclosure is— (a) permitted or required under any enactment applicable to the Regulator, including, for the avoidance of doubt, any applicable international obligations; (b) made to— (i) the ADGM Registrar of Companies; (ii) a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator; (iii) a governmental or regulatory authority exercising powers and performing functions relating to anti-money laundering, counter terrorist financing or sanctions compliance, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise; (iv) a self regulatory body or organisation exercising and performing powers and functions in relation to financial services, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise; (v) a criminal law enforcement agency, whether in the U.A.E or otherwise, for the purpose of any criminal investigation or criminal proceedings; or (vi) a civil law enforcement agency or body, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, U.A.E or otherwise; for the purpose of assisting the performance by any such person of its functions and powers; or (c) made in good faith for the purposes of the exercise of the functions and powers of the Regulator or in order to further the Regulator's objectives.

question: What must a Relevant Person avoid when setting up or keeping accounts, especially regarding anonymous or fake names, and how does this relate to nominee accounts?
answer: A Relevant Person must not set up or keep anonymous accounts, accounts with fake names, or nominee accounts where the account is in one person's name but actually controlled by someone else whose identity is hidden. This rule is backed by Federal AML Legislation, which also bans accounts under borrowed or fake names, or those identified only by numbers without naming the account holders. These rules make sure that all accounts can be traced back to their real owners, helping to stop illegal activities like money laundering. Together, these prohibitions ensure that people can't hide their identities by using nominee accounts or fake names, which helps keep the financial system honest [#SRC:10448f13-24a6-4b31-831f-779fc02b8131] and [#TGT:b2f33a11-b7ac-4936-b314-afb6f0d5a427].
source_passage_text: A Relevant Person should note that, in addition to the prohibition in Rule 7.2.3 against knowingly establishing anonymous accounts, accounts in a fictitious name or nominee accounts, the Federal AML Legislation also prohibits the opening of accounts held under borrowed, mock or fake names or accounts designated solely with numbers and without the names of account holders.
target_passage_text: A Relevant Person must not knowingly establish or maintain an anonymous account, an account in a fictitious name, or a nominee account which is held in the name of one Person but which is controlled by or held for the benefit of another Person whose true identity has not been disclosed to the Relevant Person.

question: When must a Mining Reporting Entity disclose changes in production targets, and how does this relate to the definition of Inside Information concerning Financial Instruments?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is required to disclose any material changes in its production targets if such changes could significantly affect the price of Financial Instruments. This obligation arises when the information is not generally available and is of a precise nature, directly or indirectly relating to the entity or the financial instruments involved. The disclosure obligation is triggered under specific regulatory provisions when the information, if made public, would likely influence the market price of the related instruments. This aligns with the definition of Inside Information, which encompasses precise, non-public information that could impact the price of Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities. Therefore, the entity must evaluate whether the production changes meet these criteria to determine if disclosure is necessary, ensuring compliance with the regulatory framework that governs market transparency and integrity [#SRC:09aca426-0526-4305-9aa4-12e87c9b3c96] and [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977].
source_passage_text: Production Targets-Disclosure requirements . If a Mining Reporting Entity becomes aware that its Production results will differ materially (up or down) from any Production Target it has disclosed, it may have a legal obligation to disclose this. This obligation to disclose may arise under Rule 7.2.1 and section 95(2) of FSMR, in order to disclose information that would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price... of Financial Instruments.
target_passage_text: In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which— (a) is not generally available; (b) relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and (c) would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: When does sharing information become market abuse under the rules and definitions?
answer: Sharing information becomes market abuse when the information gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression about a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity. This happens if the person sharing the information knew or should have known that it was false or misleading. This rule is important because it helps keep the market fair by making sure everyone gets the right information. Both the FSMR and the related definitions agree on this point, showing that it's not just about what you know, but also about what you should know. This means you can't just say you didn't know the information was wrong if you should have known it was misleading [#SRC:accbcc67-a2f7-4216-a57f-2e829b782418] and [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef].
source_passage_text: Section 92(6) of the FSMR provides that Behaviour will amount to Market Abuse where it: "...consists of the dissemination of information by any means which gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity by a person who knew or could reasonably be expected to have known that the information was false or misleading".
target_passage_text: The fifth is where the Behaviour consists of the dissemination of information by any means which gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity by a person who knew or could reasonably be expected to have known that the information was false or misleading.

question: What must a Listed Entity not do with Restriction Agreements, and what must they do about holding locks on Restricted Securities?
answer: A Listed Entity must not make any changes to an executed Restriction Agreement during a Restriction Period. This rule is in place to ensure that the original terms of the agreement are preserved and not altered without proper authorization. At the same time, the Listed Entity must also make sure to get a promise from a bank, trustee, or similar entity to put a holding lock on Restricted Securities. This needs to happen within two Business Days after the securities are issued. The holding lock is important because it stops the securities from being traded or transferred without permission. Additionally, the holding lock cannot be removed unless the Regulator gives written approval first. These rules help maintain control and oversight over how Restricted Securities are handled [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] and [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76].
source_passage_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. During a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement must not: (1) amend an executed Restriction Agreement; or (2) ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9.
target_passage_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: Under what conditions must a Mining Reporting Entity comply with specific rules when disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, and how does this relate to the general obligation for disclosures about Exploration Targets and related statements?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is generally required to prepare disclosures involving Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard and the relevant chapter. However, when disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, the entity does not need to comply with the standard rule if it adheres to specific alternative rules. These alternative rules include compliance with Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6. This exception allows the entity to bypass the general obligation under certain conditions, provided the alternative compliance requirements are met. This ensures that while flexibility is granted in specific cases, the integrity and reliability of the disclosures are maintained through adherence to alternative standards [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d].
source_passage_text: Where a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation the Mining Reporting Entity does not need to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1) provided the Mining Reporting Entity complies with: (1) Rule 11.7.2; (2) Rule 11.7.3; (3) Rule 11.7.4; and (4) Rule 11.7.6.
target_passage_text: Requirements for all disclosures. A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with: (1) a Mining Reporting Standard; and (2) this chapter.

question: When a big change happens, like a new Prospectus, what does the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund need to do?
answer: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund needs to tell the Regulator about any big changes as soon as possible. This includes giving details about what happened and, if there's a new Prospectus, providing a copy of it. The notification should follow the format the Regulator wants. Some examples of big changes are if the Fund Manager plans to leave, if a new manager is coming in, or if important service providers change. The Fund Manager has to do this within seven days of knowing about the change. This helps the Regulator keep track of important updates that might affect how the Passported Fund is run, making sure everything stays in line with ADGM rules [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] and [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898].
source_passage_text: The notification referred to in Rule 6.6.2 must be in such prescribed form as the Regulator may direct from time to time. At a minimum, the notification must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event and (where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced) a copy of the new Prospectus.
target_passage_text: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. In particular (but without limitation), a Fund Manager or the governing body or trustee of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable (and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware) of any of the following events: (a) the Fund Manager intends to retire as manager of the Passported Fund; (b) it is proposed that a successor manager will be appointed in relation to the Passported Fund; (c) the Fund Manager has been removed or replaced as manager of the Passported Fund; (d) any material service provider to the Passported Fund (including, without limitation, any custodian) or an Agent or Licensed Person resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced; (e) the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced; (f) winding-up of the Passported Fund has commenced; or (g) the Fund Manager intends to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission (or any conditions contained in that Financial Service Permission).

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person provide credit to a Related Person on more favourable terms, despite the general prohibition on such exposures?
answer: An Authorised Person may provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those offered to non-Related Persons if the credit policy is specifically an Employee credit policy. This policy must be widely available to Employees and receive approval from the Authorised Person's Governing Body or its delegate. Additionally, the policy must clearly outline the terms, conditions, and limits for providing credit to Employees, both at individual and aggregate levels. It is also essential that the policy includes mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance with its terms and conditions, with immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate in case of any deviations or breaches. This exception allows for the provision of credit under more favourable terms while maintaining oversight and compliance, as required [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] and permitted [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496].
source_passage_text: Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must: (a) set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit; (b) subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and (c) if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that: (i) require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and (ii) exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.
target_passage_text: Credit Risk policy. The prohibition in Rule 4.4.4(b) does not apply to Providing Credit to a Related Person under a credit policy on terms (such as for credit assessment, tenor, interest rates, amortisation schedules and requirements for Collateral) that are more favourable than those on which it provides credit to Persons who are not Related Persons, provided the credit policy: (a) is an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person; (b) is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; (c) clearly sets out the terms, conditions and limits (both at individual and aggregate levels) on which credit is to be provided to such Employees; and (d) requires adequate mechanisms to ensure on going compliance with the terms and conditions of that credit policy, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate where there is a deviation from or a breach of the terms and conditions or procedures applicable to the provision of such credit for timely and appropriate action.

question: What steps must an Authorised Person take to identify its capital instruments for Available Stable Funding, and how should they calculate the maturity of these instruments?
answer: An Authorised Person must first identify its capital instruments for Available Stable Funding by checking if they meet certain eligibility rules, excluding any Tier 2 capital instruments with less than one year of maturity. After identifying eligible instruments, the Authorised Person must calculate the maturity of each instrument or liability. This calculation is based on the earliest time an investor can choose to redeem their investment or withdraw the funding. By following these steps, the Authorised Person ensures that only suitable and properly matured instruments are included in the Available Stable Funding, adhering to the necessary regulatory guidelines [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] and [#TGT:68a2eabe-76b5-4a9c-8bad-d8c20fd492aa].
source_passage_text: Available Stable Funding (ASF). Subject to Rule A10.4.6, an Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments that are to be included in its Available Stable Funding by considering the capital elements that are meet the requirements for eligibility under: (a) Rule 3.10.2; (b) Rule 3.11.2; and (c) Rule 3.12.2, excluding all Tier 2 capital instruments with residual maturity of less than one year.
target_passage_text: Available Stable Funding (ASF). In determining the residual maturity of an instrument captured under Rule A10.4.2 or Rule A10.4.3 or any other liability that is to be included in the Available Stable Funding, an Authorised Person must calculate the residual maturity of each instrument or liability as being that period up to the earliest point in time at which an investor has the right to exercise their right to redeem their investment or withdraw that source of funding.

question: When do the rules about what must be in a prospectus not apply to someone offering a Unit?
answer: The rules about what must be in a prospectus, including its content and structure, do not apply when the prospectus is about Units of Funds. These specific rules are found in the Fund Rules instead. This is because section 57(1) of the FSMR says that chapter 4 of the Rulebook does not apply to Fund Prospectuses. Also, the rules in the relevant Chapter do not apply to a person making an Offer of a Unit. This means that both the Issuer and the person offering the Unit are not required to follow the usual prospectus rules in these cases. This setup makes sure that there are special rules for Fund Prospectuses, which are different from other offers, so everything is clear and follows the right guidelines [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] and [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a].
source_passage_text: The Prospectus requirements including content and structure in chapter 4 of this Rulebook do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules. Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of this Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses.
target_passage_text: The provisions in this Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter shall not apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit.

question: Under what conditions may a Payment Service User and Provider agree to alter the notification period for unauthorised transactions, and what must the User do to ensure entitlement to redress?
answer: A Payment Service User and its Payment Service Provider may agree in writing to apply a different time period for notifying unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions, provided the User is not a Natural Person. However, to be entitled to redress, the Payment Service User must notify its Payment Service Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date upon becoming aware of the issue. This agreement on a different time period does not negate the obligation for timely notification to secure redress, as required [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] and permitted [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297].
source_passage_text: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (charges for information); (b) Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4) (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 19.18.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (d) Rule 19.20.1 (Payer or Payees liability for unauthorised transactions); (e) Rules 19.17.1 and 19.17.2 (requests for refund); (f) Rule 19.14.3 (revocation of a Payment Order); (g) Rule 19.21.2 (defective execution of Payer-initiated transactions); (h) Rule 19.21.3 (defective execution of Payee-initiated transactions); (i) Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1.
target_passage_text: A Payment Service User is entitled to redress under this Chapter only if it notifies its Payment Service Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the debit date, on becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction.

question: When can't Securities related to a Prospectus be offered, and what makes an offer exempt according to the Regulator?
answer: Securities related to a Prospectus can't be offered for subscription or sale unless the Prospectus is current, unless there's an exemption. The Regulator says an offer is exempt if it meets certain conditions, like being aimed only at Professional Clients or involving a small number of people over a year. Other exemptions include offers with a high minimum purchase amount or those tied to specific business events like mergers. These rules help make sure that some offers can go ahead without needing a current Prospectus, balancing flexibility in the market with protecting investors [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] and [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].
source_passage_text: Except where an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 applies, the Securities to which a Prospectus relates must not be offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus unless that Prospectus is a current Prospectus.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, the Regulator prescribes the following to be circumstances in which an Offer is an Exempt Offer: (1) an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients; (2) an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period, excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons; (3) an Offer where the total consideration to be paid by a Person to acquire the Securities is at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (4) an Offer where the Securities are denominated in amounts of at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (5) an Offer where the total aggregate consideration for the Securities offered is less than $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency, calculated over a period of 12 months; (6) an Offer where Shares are issued in substitution for Shares of the same class as already issued, where the issue of the new Shares does not involve any increase in the issued Share capital; (7) an Offer where the Securities are Convertibles issued under a Prospectus to existing members or creditors of the Issuer or a member of its Group and there is no additional consideration to be paid; (8) an Offer where the Securities are offered in connection with a Takeover and a document is made available containing information which is considered by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (9) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a merger if a document is available containing information which is regarded by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (10) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue where: (a) the Securities are of a class subject to Reporting Entity disclosure; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Securities including rights attaching to those Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (11) an Offer where the Shares are offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Shareholders free of charge or dividends paid out in the form of Shares of the same class as the Shares in respect of which the dividends are paid, and a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Shares and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (12) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted to an existing or former Director or Employee, or any Close Relative of such a Director or Employee, of the Issuer or a member of the same Group as the Issuer and: (a) the Issuer or the member of the Group already has its Securities admitted to trading on a Regulated Exchange; and (b) a document is made available to the offerees containing information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; or (13) other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk, an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility.

question: When a Listed Entity seeks to allot, issue, or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, what obligations must the Board fulfill to ensure equality of treatment among holders of the same class of Securities?
answer: When a Listed Entity intends to allot, issue, or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, it must first obtain approval from the Regulator. This action can alter the Share capital, impacting the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest. Concurrently, the Board of the Listed Entity is obligated to ensure equality of treatment for all holders of Securities of a particular class or type. This means that despite the introduction of Weighted Voting Rights, the Board must maintain equal treatment concerning all rights attached to those Securities, as required by the relevant rules. This dual requirement ensures that while the entity may alter voting rights with regulatory approval, it must also uphold the principle of equal treatment among Security holders, thereby balancing the flexibility to innovate in share structures with the obligation to maintain fairness and equity among investors [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] and [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae].
source_passage_text: Weighted Voting Rights. A Listed Entity may, upon approval from the Regulator, allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, altering its Share capital in relation to the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest (as established in Rule 9.3.3).
target_passage_text: Equality of treatment. Subject to Rules 9.3.14 to 9.3.17, the Board of a Listed Entity must ensure equality of treatment of all holders of Securities of a particular class or type in respect of all rights attaching to the Securities of that class or type of Securities.

question: When is a Fund Prospectus not considered approved, and what makes a Prospectus officially approved by the Regulator?
answer: A Fund Prospectus is not considered approved unless the Regulator gives the Applicant a notice saying it has approved the Prospectus or any Supplementary Prospectus. If the Prospectus has multiple documents, all must be approved. For a Prospectus to be officially approved, it must meet the Regulator's requirements as set in the Rules. Also, when the Regulations mention a Prospectus, they usually mean an Approved Prospectus, unless it clearly means something else. This means both the specific approval notice and the general rules must be followed for a Prospectus to be officially 'Approved' [#SRC:e4f01dc3-b9ba-4fbb-a37e-72e4a4dfb5ff] and [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1].
source_passage_text: A Fund Prospectus is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval: (a) of the Prospectus or Supplementary Prospectus, as the case may be; and (b) in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)— (a) a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and (b) a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: Under what circumstances may a Recognised Clearing House not be considered non-compliant with the Recognition Requirement, particularly in relation to procedures for detecting and managing settlement failures?
answer: A Recognised Clearing House will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled. This implies that while the procedures to detect and deal with the failure of a Member or participant to settle are crucial, the inability to settle a specific transaction does not automatically result in non-compliance. The regulatory framework considers various aspects such as rules and practices for clearing and settlement, arrangements for matching trades, and procedures for monitoring settlement performance. However, the emphasis is on the overall arrangements and procedures rather than the outcome of individual transactions. Therefore, the scope of compliance is broader and not solely dependent on the settlement of every transaction, allowing for some flexibility in the operational challenges faced by clearing houses [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] as required [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES Spot Commodity Settlement Facilities (SCSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 4.3.3, in determining whether there are satisfactory arrangements for securing the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions, the FSRA may have regard to the SCSFs: a) rules and practices relating to clearing and settlement, including its arrangements with another Person for the provision of clearing and settlement services; b) arrangements for matching trades and ensuring that the parties are in agreement about trade details; c) arrangements for making deliveries and payments, in all relevant jurisdictions; d) procedures to detect and deal with the failure of a Member (or participants) to settle in accordance with its rules; e) arrangements for taking action to settle a trade if a Member (or participant) does not settle in accordance with its rules; f) arrangements for monitoring its Members settlement performance; and g) Default Rules and default procedures.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Clearing House will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled.

question: When can an Authorised Person use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure, and when do they have to use a 20% risk weight for items from other banks?
answer: An Authorised Person can use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure if it is categorised as a cash item and meets the conditions of Rule 4.12.3. However, they must use a 20% risk weight for cheques, drafts, and other items from other banks if these are payable immediately or are being collected. This means that while some exposures can be treated as less risky and given a 0% risk weight, others, like certain banking items, are considered riskier and must be assigned a 20% risk weight. This helps ensure that the financial institution properly accounts for the risk associated with different types of financial items [#SRC:881a93fe-965d-4247-98b7-13b0248c8b98] [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8].
source_passage_text: Subject to Rule 4.12.3, an Authorised Person may apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure categorised as a cash item.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must apply a 20% risk weight to cheques, drafts and other items drawn on other banking institutions that are either payable immediately upon presentation or that are in the process of collection.

question: What do Domestic Firms need to do to meet both capital ratio rules and capital resource requirements?
answer: Domestic Firms need to make sure they follow the rules for capital ratios, which include keeping a CET1 Capital ratio of at least 6.0%, a T1 Capital ratio of at least 8.0%, and a Capital Resources ratio of at least 10.0% compared to their Total Risk Exposure Amount. At the same time, they must also have enough Capital Resources to meet or exceed their Capital Requirement at all times. This means they need to balance their risk exposure with the required capital levels to stay compliant with regulations [#SRC:f70e13d5-e8a2-464c-871c-7306c244548d] and [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e].
source_passage_text: Capital ratios. Subject to 3.2.3, an Authorised Person must ensure that it complies with the following requirements at all times. (a) The ratio of CET1 Capital to Total Risk Exposure Amount must not be less than 6.0%. (b) The ratio of T1 Capital to Total Risk Exposure Amount must not be less than 8.0%. (c) The ratio of Capital Resources to Total Risk Exposure Amount must not be less than 10.0%. Guidance In Rule 3.16.2 CET1 Capital is that calculated at step A3, T1 Capital is that calculated at step A7 and Capital Resources is that calculated at step A11 of Rule 3.15.3.
target_passage_text: Domestic Firms – adequate capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must have, at all times, Capital Resources which equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement.

question: When can the Regulator cancel a Recognition Order for a Recognised Body or Remote Body?
answer: The Regulator can cancel a Recognition Order for a Recognised Body or a Remote Body if the body itself asks for it or agrees to it. This means that the Recognised Body or Remote Body must either request the cancellation or give their consent for it to happen. The process ensures that the Recognised or Remote Body is involved in the decision, making it a collaborative action. This cancellation is allowed as required [#TGT:3ef78fff-df9e-4b9b-b709-a575f953bbda] and permitted [#SRC:62908d5d-eb70-4217-a2b5-520be929d63f], providing a clear and structured way to manage Recognition Orders. This approach ensures that the bodies have a say in their recognition status, while the Regulator maintains the authority to oversee and implement the cancellation when necessary.
source_passage_text: With consent . We may revoke a Recognition Order at the request or otherwise with the consent of the relevant Recognised Body or Remote Body pursuant to section 134(1) of FSMR.
target_passage_text: (1) A Recognition Order in respect of a Recognised Body or in respect of a Remote Body may be revoked by an order made by the Regulator at the request, or with the consent, of the Recognised Body or Remote Body concerned.

question: Under what conditions must the Regulator suspend a Listed Entity's Securities without prior notice, and when may it require an Institution to suspend Financial Instruments to protect market interests?
answer: The Regulator is obligated to suspend a Listed Entity's Securities without prior notice in certain circumstances, such as when exercising Own-Initiative Powers or issuing a stop order. However, the Regulator must still provide the affected party a right to representation within a specified period after the decision. Concurrently, the Regulator may require an Institution to suspend or remove Financial Instruments from Trading to protect investor interests or ensure the orderly functioning of financial markets. This dual framework allows the Regulator to act swiftly in urgent situations while maintaining procedural fairness by allowing post-decision representations. The Regulator's ability to act without prior notice is balanced by its power to mandate suspensions for broader market protection, ensuring both immediate and long-term regulatory objectives are met [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c] [#TGT:c13083a9-1aa5-43a4-805b-03a0e80a5b85].
source_passage_text: Relevant considerations. In certain circumstances we do not have to give an affected person advance notice of our proposed action, or the chance to make prior representations, before the action takes effect. In such circumstances, we are still obliged to give the affected person a right of representation within a specified period from the date on which the decision is made and communicated to the affected person. We are obliged to consider any representations made by, or on behalf of, the affected person during that period. Decisions that might be made without giving the affected person a right to make representations before the decision takes effect include: (a) the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers, applying the procedures in sections 42 and 124C of FSMR; (b) variation of Approval under section 48 of FSMR; (c) discontinuance or suspension of Listing of any Securities under section 53 of FSMR; (d) the issuing of a stop order under section 71 of FSMR; and (e) suspension of a Listed Entity's Securities from the Official List under section 180 of FSMR,
target_passage_text: Regulator's power to require suspension or removal of Financial Instruments from Trading The Regulator may, for the purpose of protecting— (a) the interests of investors; or (b) the orderly functioning of the financial markets; require an Institution or a class of Institutions to suspend or remove a Financial Instrument from Trading.

question: What are the obligations for an Authorised Person operating as a Cell Company and holding a Financial Services Permission for Captive Insurers or Insurance Special Purpose Vehicles regarding annual supervision fees to the Regulator?
answer: An Authorised Person operating as a Cell Company must pay an additional annual supervision fee of $8,000 to the Regulator, plus $1,000 for each Cell. Additionally, if the Authorised Person holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, they are required to pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 for either or both activities. These fees ensure that the Regulator can effectively oversee the operations of both Cell Companies and entities involved in insurance activities, maintaining compliance with regulatory standards. The combination of these obligations highlights the financial responsibilities that such Authorised Persons must fulfill to continue their operations within the regulatory framework [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] and [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].
source_passage_text: Cell Companies. An Authorised Person under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 that operates as a Cell Company must pay to the Regulator an additional annual supervision fee of $8,000 for the Cell Company plus $1,000 for each Cell.
target_passage_text: Captive Insurers and Insurance Special Purpose Vehicles. An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $5,000 for either or both Regulated Activities.

question: What are the payment obligations for an Authorised Person operating as a Cell Company and holding a Financial Services Permission for Captive Insurers or Insurance Special Purpose Vehicles?
answer: An Authorised Person operating as a Cell Company must pay an application fee of $1,000 to the Regulator for each additional Cell it wishes to add after obtaining its Financial Services Permission. Concurrently, if the Authorised Person holds a Financial Services Permission to conduct Regulated Activities as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, they are required to pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 for either or both activities. These financial obligations ensure that the Regulator receives the necessary fees for both the expansion of Cell Companies and the ongoing supervision of Captive Insurers and Insurance Special Purpose Vehicles. The dual fee structure underscores the regulatory framework's emphasis on both initial and ongoing compliance costs associated with operating these specialized financial entities [#SRC:31302f70-ed5e-4f1a-860f-140416c5d9e8] and [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].
source_passage_text: Cell Companies. An Authorised Person under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 that operates as a Cell Company must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $1,000 for each Cell that it wishes to add after it has received its Financial Services Permission.
target_passage_text: Captive Insurers and Insurance Special Purpose Vehicles. An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $5,000 for either or both Regulated Activities.

question: What must a person not do when giving information under a requirement if they know it might be false or misleading?
answer: A person must not provide information that they know is false or misleading, or do so recklessly, when they are supposed to be complying with a requirement. This rule is important to make sure that all information given is accurate and truthful. If someone deliberately or carelessly gives false or misleading information, it is considered a serious violation of the rules. The regulations are clear that such actions are not allowed because they can interfere with the work of the regulatory body. This ensures that the regulatory body can do its job properly without being misled by incorrect information. The rules focus on both deliberate and careless actions to make sure everyone is honest and careful when providing information. These prohibitions help keep the regulatory process trustworthy and reliable, making sure everyone follows the rules for truthfulness and accuracy as required [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] and permitted [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23].
source_passage_text: Non-compliance with requirements. A person that deliberately or recklessly provides information that is false or misleading in a material particular in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement commits a contravention of FSMR section 214(4). Engaging in conduct that is intended to obstruct us in the exercise of our investigative powers by any means is also a contravention. Such obstruction could include: (a) the failure to attend at a specified time and place to answer questions; (b) the falsification, concealment or destruction of documents; (c) the failure to give or produce information or documents specified by us; (d) the failure to permit us access to premises; and (e) the failure to provide assistance in relation to an investigation.
target_passage_text: A person shall not, in purported compliance with a requirement imposed on him under this Part— (a) provide information which he knows to be false or misleading in a material particular; or (b) recklessly provide information which is false or misleading in a material particular.

question: What steps must a Recognised Investment Exchange follow to determine if a participant or Member has exceeded a position limit on a Derivative, and what capabilities must they have to ensure compliance?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange is required to have the necessary capabilities to ascertain whether a participant or Member has surpassed any position limit set for a Derivative or class of Derivatives. This determination process involves a comprehensive assessment of various positions. Specifically, the Exchange must consider any position held by another Person who is directly or indirectly controlled by the participant or Member. Additionally, positions held by other Persons acting under an express or implied agreement, as if they were held by the participant or Member, must also be included in the evaluation. Furthermore, any position held in respect of an Option on the Derivative contract should be calculated on a Derivative equivalent basis. These steps ensure that the Exchange can accurately determine compliance with position limits, thereby fulfilling its regulatory obligations [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8] and adhering to procedural requirements [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17].
source_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange must have the capabilities to determine whether a participant or Member has exceeded any position limit set in respect of any Derivative or class of Derivatives in accordance with Rule 3.3.9.
target_passage_text: When determining whether a position limit imposed in respect of a Derivative has been exceeded by a participant or Member trading in the Derivative, a Recognised Investment Exchange must take into account: (a) any position held by any other Person directly, or indirectly, controlled by the participant or Member; (b) any position held by any other Person acting, pursuant to an express or implied agreement or understanding, as if such position were held by the participant or Member; and (c) any position held in respect of an Option on the Derivative contract, calculated on a Derivative equivalent basis.

question: What must an Insurer do about the value of reinsurance expected to be received and how should it handle premium liabilities for future claims?
answer: An Insurer must treat as an asset the value of reinsurance and other recoveries that are expected to be received for claims, following International Financial Reporting Standards. At the same time, the Insurer must also treat as a liability the premium liability, which includes the value of future claim payments and related settlement costs. These liabilities are for future events covered by policies that are active as of the Solvency Reference Date. This approach ensures that the Insurer properly accounts for both the expected recoveries and the potential liabilities, keeping its financial records accurate and compliant [#SRC:e6345a04-a9de-4dbf-8085-91eee4cffec6] and [#TGT:3c34e221-794b-4399-b4bd-b38a5f2a10c6].
source_passage_text: An Insurer must treat as an asset the value of reinsurance and other recoveries expected to be received in respect of claims referred to in Rules 5.4.7 and 5.4.8 in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards.
target_passage_text: An Insurer must treat as a liability, the premium liability, which is the value of future claim payments and associated direct and indirect settlement costs, arising from future events insured under policies that are in force as at the Solvency Reference Date.

question: What must a Petroleum Reporting Entity ensure is included in the disclosure when presenting new material estimates of Prospective Resources that have not been previously disclosed?
answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must ensure that the disclosure of new material estimates of Prospective Resources, which have not been previously disclosed, includes several critical elements. These elements are: the types of permits or licenses held for the disclosed estimates, a description of the estimation method, and any further exploration activities planned, including studies, data acquisition, evaluation work, and exploration drilling, along with the expected timing of these activities. Additionally, the disclosure must contain an assessment of the likelihood of discovery and development associated with the estimates and an explanation of relevant risk factors. Furthermore, the disclosure should also include an explanation of how new data and information have affected these estimates, as well as any changes or additions to previously disclosed information related to Prospective Resources. This comprehensive approach ensures transparency and thoroughness in reporting, aligning with regulatory requirements [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] and [#TGT:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55].
source_passage_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity making a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relating to the estimates; (2) an explanation of the new data and information; (3) an explanation of how the new data and information has affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources; and (4) any changes or additions to the information previously disclosed relating to: (a) Prospective Resources under Rules 12.8.1(1) to 12.8.1(4); (b) Contingent Resources under Rules 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5); and (c) Petroleum Reserves under Rules 12.12.1(1) to 12.12.1(7).
target_passage_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity disclosing estimates of Prospective Resources that are material and that have not previously been disclosed by the Petroleum Reporting Entity, must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licenses held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity for the disclosed estimates of Prospective Resources; (2) a description of: (a) the method of estimation; (b) any further Exploration activities to be undertaken (including studies, further data acquisition and evaluation work, and Exploration drilling); and (c) the expected timing of those Exploration activities; (3) the Petroleum Reporting Entity’s assessment of the likelihood of discovery and development associated with the disclosed estimates of Prospective Resources; and (4) an explanation of the relevant risk factors.

question: What steps must a Mining Reporting Entity follow for subsequent disclosures related to forecast financial information, and what are the obligations regarding the assumptions used in the initial disclosure?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure that any subsequent disclosure related to forecast financial information, following an initial disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, adheres to specific procedural steps. The subsequent disclosure must reference the earlier compliant disclosure and confirm that all material assumptions from the initial disclosure remain unchanged. Additionally, if the forecast is based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partially on an Exploration Target, the entity must include prominent statements as required. Concurrently, the initial disclosure obligations require the inclusion of all material economic assumptions, a statement if these are commercially sensitive, and an explanation of the methodology used. The entity must also disclose the Production Target from which the forecast is derived, ensuring compliance with all relevant rules. These obligations ensure transparency and consistency in financial reporting, maintaining the integrity of the disclosed information [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] and [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_passage_text: If a Mining Reporting Entity has made a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, then any subsequent disclosure in relation to forecast financial information derived from a Production Target need not include the information in Rule 11.9.2 where the subsequent disclosure: (1) references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.9.2; (2) contains a statement confirming that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure upon which the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target is based continue to apply and have not materially changed; (3) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d); and (4) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is based in part upon an Exploration Target, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b).
target_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: What must an Authorised Person do before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, and under what conditions may this classification occur?
answer: An Authorised Person must, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, ensure that such a Person has been given a prior written notification of the classification as a Market Counterparty in relation to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction, or in respect of all Regulated Activities and Transactions. Additionally, the Professional Client must not have requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in the notice. This obligation is necessary to ensure that the Professional Client is fully informed and has the opportunity to contest the classification if desired. The classification may occur if the Person qualifies as a deemed Professional Client in accordance with the relevant rules and the requirements specified have been met. This dual requirement ensures both compliance with procedural obligations and the proper exercise of classification permissions [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3] as permitted [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person may classify a Person as a Market Counterparty if: (i) that Person qualifies as a deemed Professional Client in accordance with Rule 2.4.2; and (ii) the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) have been met.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, ensure that such a Person has: (i) been given a prior written notification of the classification as a Market Counterparty in relation to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction, or in respect of all Regulated Activities and Transactions; and (ii) not requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in the notice.

question: Under what circumstances does the prohibition on certain transactions not apply to a Listed Entity or its Related Party, considering the scope of application?
answer: The prohibition on certain transactions does not apply to a Listed Entity or its Related Party in several specific circumstances. These include transactions conducted in the ordinary course of business, those not exceeding 0.25% of the Listed Entity's net assets, and transactions made under an approved Employee Incentive Scheme. Additionally, exemptions exist for the issuance of new Securities under certain conditions, transactions agreed upon before a party became a Related Party, and credit arrangements on normal commercial terms. Other exemptions include indemnities or insurance for Directors, underwriting arrangements with standard commercial terms, and joint investment arrangements where the Related Party's contribution is limited to 25% of the Listed Entity's contribution, provided an independent third party confirms the fairness of terms. These exemptions ensure that while the section applies to Listed Entities and their Related Parties, certain transactions are not subject to the prohibitions, allowing for operational flexibility within defined boundaries [#SRC:7953d205-7abd-46be-bf3a-74b14b3d7c51] and [#TGT:8cb293df-7ea8-41a7-84d7-d5eeba98e7e1].
source_passage_text: Application. This section applies, subject to Rule 9.5.4, to: (1) a Listed Entity; and (2) a Related Party of such a Listed Entity.
target_passage_text: Exemptions. The requirements in this section do not apply to a transaction referred to in Rule 9.5.2(2): (1) where the transaction is made in the ordinary course of business; (2) where it, or any series of transactions with the same Related Party in any 12 month period, does not exceed 0.25% of the value of the net assets of the Listed Entity as stated in its most recent financial reports; (3) where it is made in accordance with the terms of an Employee Incentive Scheme approved by the Board of the Listed Entity; (4) where it involves the issue of new Securities for cash or pursuant to the exercise of conversion or subscription rights attaching to Securities issued to existing Shareholders where the Securities are traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Regulated Exchange; (5) where its terms were agreed before any Person became a Related Party; (6) where it involves a grant of credit, including the lending of money or the guaranteeing of a loan, to: (a) the Related Party on normal commercial terms; (b) a Director of the Listed Entity or a member of its Group for an amount and on terms no more favourable than those offered to employees of the Group generally; or (c) by the Related Party on normal commercial terms and on an unsecured basis; (7) where it involves granting an indemnity to or maintaining a Contract of Insurance for a Director of the Listed Entity or a member of its Group; (8) where it involves underwriting by a Related Party of Securities issued by the Listed Entity or a member of its Group if the consideration to be paid for the underwriting is no more than the usual commercial underwriting consideration and is the same as that to be paid to the other underwriters, if any, other than where the Related Party is underwriting Securities it is entitled to take up as part of the issuance; or (9) where it involves a joint investment arrangement between the Listed Entity (or a member of its Group) and a Related Party for each to invest in, or provide finance to, another undertaking or asset if: (a) the amount contributed by the Related Party is not more than 25% of the amount contributed by the Listed Entity (or a member of its Group); and (b) an independent third party has provided a prior written opinion that the terms and circumstances of the contribution of finance by the Listed Entity or a member of its Group are no less favourable than those applying to the contribution of finance by the Related Party.

question: What is the nature of Guidance issued under the Financial Services and Markets Regulations, and how does it relate to the Rules and Market Rules of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority?
answer: Guidance issued under the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR) is characterized as indicative and non-binding. It serves as a supplementary tool to the FSMR and the Market Rules of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA). This Guidance can take the form of notations made and issued by the Regulator to accompany the Rules, or it may consist of separate Guidance issued by the Regulator that has not been incorporated into the Rules. The purpose of such Guidance is to provide clarity and direction without imposing mandatory requirements, thereby allowing for flexibility in interpretation and application. This approach ensures that while the Guidance aids in understanding the regulatory framework, it does not carry the force of law, thus maintaining its non-binding nature. The issuance of Guidance under section 15(2) of the FSMR underscores its role in facilitating compliance and understanding within the financial services sector, while not constraining the regulated entities with additional binding obligations [#SRC:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f] [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd].
source_passage_text: INTRODUCTION This Guidance is issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (FSMR). It should be read in conjunction with FSMR and the Market Rules (MKT) of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA).
target_passage_text: Guidance is indicative and non binding and may comprise— (a) Guidance made and issued by the Regulator as notations to the Rules; and (b) any Guidance issued by the Regulator which has not been incorporated into the Rules.

question: What must an Authorised Person do to comply with the Credit Risk Capital Requirement obligations, considering the calculation components and applicable rules?
answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) in accordance with the applicable Rules in Chapter 4. This obligation is part of the broader framework governing the overall Capital Requirement, which includes CRCOM as a critical component. The calculation of CRCOM is not only governed by the rules in Chapter 4 but is also supplemented by additional guidelines in App4. This ensures that the Authorised Person adheres to a comprehensive and structured approach when determining its capital requirements. The integration of these rules and guidelines is essential for maintaining compliance with the regulatory standards set forth for capital adequacy. Therefore, the Authorised Person must ensure that all calculations are performed accurately and in alignment with these specified rules to meet the regulatory expectations for credit risk management [#TGT:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a] and to fulfill the overall Capital Requirement as provided [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166].
source_passage_text: The Credit Risk Capital Requirement (also referred to in these Rules as CRCOM) is a component of the calculation of the overall Capital Requirement of an Authorised Person, as provided in Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2. The Rules in this Part 3, supplemented by App4, govern the manner of calculation of the CRCOM.
target_passage_text: CRCOM. An Authorised Person must calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with the applicable Rules in Chapter 4.

question: What must an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm do to ensure there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due, considering both liquidity and capital resources requirements?
answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm is obligated to maintain capital resources at all times, ensuring they are of the types and amounts specified by the relevant rules. This requirement is essential to mitigate any significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. The firm must also maintain additional capital and liquid assets that are adequate relative to the nature, size, and complexity of its business operations. This is to ensure financial stability and compliance with regulatory obligations. Furthermore, the firm may meet its liquidity obligations by holding sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets, securing an appropriate matching future profile of cashflows, or through further borrowing. These measures collectively ensure that the firm can meet its liabilities as they become due, thereby fulfilling both liquidity and capital resource requirements as mandated [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87] and [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56].
source_passage_text: In accordance with Rule 3.2.2 or Rule 3.2.4, an Authorised Person is required to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. With specific reference to liquidity, an Authorised Person may meet its obligations in a number of ways, including: a. by holding sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets; b. by securing an appropriate matching future profile of cashflows; and c. by further borrowing.
target_passage_text: Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must: (a) have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules; (b) ensure that it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the requirement in (a) which are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due.

question: If an Authorised Person does more than one activity under Providing Money Services, how do they figure out their Capital Requirement, especially the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum?
answer: An Authorised Person doing more than one activity under Providing Money Services needs to figure out its Capital Requirement by choosing the highest from three options: the Base Capital Requirement, the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, and the Total Variable Capital Requirement. The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum depends on the Authorised Person's category and whether they hold Client Assets, Relevant Money, or Insurance Money. If they hold these, the minimum is 18/52nds of their Annual Audited Expenditure. If they are in Category 3B or 3C and don't hold these, it's 13/52nds. For those in Category 4 without Insurance Money, it's 6/52nds. This ensures they have enough capital to cover risks, as required [#TGT:69f86dbc-ee25-4811-ae4b-6688fdbb498b] and permitted [#SRC:5f303f3f-61f2-4e64-9f2d-4854a93cf582].
source_passage_text: Multiple activities under Providing Money Services. An Authorised Person undertaking more than one of the activities under Providing Money Services must calculate its Capital Requirement as the highest of, where applicable; (i) the Base Capital Requirement as set out in Section 3.3; (ii) the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum calculated in accordance with Rule 3.7.1; and (iii) the Total Variable Capital Requirement.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person, other than one that has a Financial Services Permission to carry out the Regulated Activity of Providing Third Party Services, must calculate its Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as: (a) in the case of an Authorised Person which holds Client Assets or Relevant Money or Insurance Money, 18/52nds; (b) in the case of an Authorised Person in Category 3B or 3C which does not hold Client Assets or Relevant Money or Insurance Money, 13/52nds; or (c) in the case of an Authorised Person in Category 4, which does not hold Insurance Money, 6/52nds; of the Annual Audited Expenditure, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.7.2.
